I join everyone in this parliament and the people of my electorate of Braddon on the north-west coast of Tasmania in expressing my sympathy for all the victims of the Bali bombing. What makes this even more horrendous is the number of Australians killed, injured and traumatised by the carnage in Kuta. Our media has been full of the terror, heroism and analysis of this terrible event. Harrowing stories have sickened us to the core of our national psyche. Yet through the horror have emerged stories of great courage, mateship, compassion and concern. Australians have demonstrated remarkable qualities under great duress. Our numerous emergency services personnel, members of the military forces, health services personnel, individual doctors and nurses, hospital workers, aid workers, transport organisations and government agencies have done a remarkable job and deserve our sincere thanks.

Our hearts go out to the Balinese people. They were equally innocent victims of this calculated, brutal act. There are stories of their bravery, incredible friendship and compassion. The Balinese economy relies very heavily on tourism, and I believe over 10,000 Balinese have already been affected by unemployment or the prospects of it. I am pleased to note the government's stated intention to assist the Balinese people in a variety of ways, particularly in developing health facilities and assisting individual Balinese who were injured in Kuta during the bombing. I was also disturbed to read a letter to the editor in my own newspaper criticising the government for not carrying out increased expenditure on health services in Australia to the detriment of the Balinese people. I found that extraordinary.

Like all Australians, I hope that Bali soon recovers and returns to being a tourist oasis. We can do this by hunting down and punishing those who would perpetrate similar crimes throughout our region, by working with our regional neighbours to counter such terrorist acts and by tourists specifically returning to Bali to demonstrate their determination not to let this act overtly change our way of life.

Some 92 Australians are believed to have been killed in Bali. Of the 92, 41 are from New South Wales, 23 from Victoria, 15 from Western Australia, eight from Queensland, three from South Australia, one from my home state of Tasmania and one expatriate. The total confirmed dead is 187, and about 166 are still to be formally identified. Twenty-three nationalities are among the dead or injured.

The Bali murders must harden our resolve to counter terrorist acts in our region. It is important that our resources are prioritised for this purpose. Terrorism has struck at our doorstep. We do not know for sure who the cowardly murderers are, but we will find out and we will do everything we can to bring them to justice. We do not know for sure their intention beyond senseless, cowardly evil. This happened in a location well known to be frequented by Australians. Australia will not be the same again after 12 October 2002. We have entered a new era of instability in South-East Asia, and this may not be, God forbid, the last attack. We face new uncertainties. We will be targets in future for radical terrorist groups because of what we are. We do not have an option to be neutral.

My family was in Bali, at Kuta, only four weeks ago. I can but begin to imagine how I would have felt if I had received news about my family being injured, or worse, in such an event as 12 October. On behalf of my family, I wish to offer my condolences to all those familiesâAustralian, Balinese and of many other nationsâwho have been affected by this act of evil. We must not forget the pain and suffering of those affected, especially those families who have to live with this suffering every day of their lives. For me, the impact of the Bali bombing was like the impact of Port Arthurâtragically, also a tourist holiday place. Tasmania's innocence was lost on that day, but we have learned to deal with this loss and this grief. Port Arthur continues to figure as a tourist destination but it is not the same, and nor will Australia be after 12 October.

talk.start.para: âIt is with great sadness that I rise to speak today. The events of the past week and a half have impacted upon every Australian. Together we have shared the grief and the sorrow of every family who has lost a loved one, or is nursing an injured family member. Like most of the members of this House, and all Australians, I too recall the feeling of horror and heartbreak on hearing of the deadly blast that has killed so many Australians. My next fear, that friends and the people in my electorate of Riverina would lose a beloved family member, soon became a reality. My electorate of Riverina has lost three of its brightest sons.

speech.para: Bali is a destination so many Australians, young and old, have travelled to. It is a place we feel safe and comfortable in, surrounded by friendly locals who are so keen to hear about our lucky country. It is fun: it is surrounded by sun, surf and good times. Never had we imagined that terror could strike in such an idyllic place. David Mavroudis was in Bali to relax after a hard football season. Aged 28, David died alongside his football mates doing what he loved most. Photos taken just hours before the event tell of the good time that David was having. David was the only son of John and Colleen Mavroudis of Wagga Wagga and a loving brother to his sister, Jane.

David started playing rugby league with the Magpies in the under-sevens in the early 1980s and worked his way up to play first grade in 1994 and 1995. His love of football continued as he moved to Moree for work, and then to Bathurst, ensuring he could always be found on a football field. After moving to Sydney in 1999, he quickly found himself at home with the Coogee Dolphins. The Dolphins included a number of former Riverina boys, and no doubt they shared so many stories of home. Of the 14 Dolphin players in Bali, six are believed to have passed away. Remembered for his caring attitude and concern for others, David loved his family and he loved life. He always made sure he kept in close contact with his family and friends, and he had been looking forward to a long awaited holiday.

The Mavroudis family, friends of the Hulls, now coming to terms with their loss, have received an amazing amount of support from the Wagga community. More than 200 people have visited the family, and this level of support is being repeated right around my electorate in the towns of Leeton and Coolamon, and for this I am incredibly proud of the people I represent. Many are facing drought, but in times of trouble they rally around those who need them most and they offer any support that they can. Whilst this is a heartbreaking time that we will carry with us forever, I am truly proud to be an Australian and a Riverina Australian.

David was educated at Sacred Heart Primary School, St Michael's Regional High School and Trinity Senior High School and he studied medical laboratory science at Charles Sturt University before obtaining his first job at Moree, working in a pathology lab. He then moved to Bathurst. He later moved to Coogee, as I said, but was always in constant contact with friends and family in Wagga Wagga. After arriving in Sydney, David worked part time in a laboratory while studying computer programming and on completion of his degree he started work as a computer programmer with a Sydney firm.

An accomplished sportsman, David has represented New South Wales in gymnastics as well as playing rugby league for group 9 in Wagga Wagga and the Riverina. He played halfback for Wagga Magpies, Moree Boars and St Patrick's Bathurst and Coogee Dolphins. David also loved horseracing. Melbourne Cup winning jockey and family friend Jim Cassidy wore a black armband in the weekend's Caulfield Cup ride as a tribute to David.

As treasurer of the Dolphins, David donated a portion of the year's fundraising to charities before organising the club's trip to Bali. That is just the sort of person he wasâjust so generous. He was well known and liked at the Clovelly Hotel and the Coogee Palace in Sydney. David, always a Wagga Wagga boy at heart, died with his good friend, fellow Dolphins team-mate Clint Thompson. Clint, 29, formerly of Leeton, was holidaying on the island together with his many mates from Coogee Beach Dolphins Rugby League Club on their end-of-year footy trip. He worked 27 days straight to earn himself a 10-day holiday in Bali. Sadly, it lasted just 36 hours. Clint died with five of his team-mates. According to reports, the six boys were all found together, a true sign of what good friends they were.

Clint's mother, Sandra Thompson, has taken comfort from the fact that Clint was with his friends, doing what he lovedâhe was partying, enjoying all that life could offer him before it was tragically taken from him. Clint is the son of Sandra and Robert Thompson of Leeton and he was the second eldest in a family of seven children. According to his mother, Clint acted like the father of his siblings. He had five brothers, Trent, Ryan, Brock, Zaide and Kaleb, and a sister, Farrah. A number of his brothers played with him at the Coogee Beach Dolphins.

Former Leeton men Anthony Ellis and Dean Kefford, together with their team-mates, searched for their missing friends only to discover that they had not survived the blast. They both searched all day through the hospital until they found Clint's body. A renowned rugby league player, Clint went through the junior grades of the Leeton Greens before playing senior football for the club. He was a polished backline player on the wing, in the centres or in the fullback position. Clint was a popular personality in Leeton football circles and quickly became a well-known identity as the president and as a player with the Coogee Dolphins.

Educated in Leeton, Clint moved to Sydney nine years ago and studied three nights a week for three years to earn his management degree. He then started work as an area and development manager for the Mildara Blass company. Although this loss is so extreme for the gregarious and happy Thompson family, it was so humbling to hear them urging the Australian people not to hate and not to vilify those people who live in Australia as though they were responsible. `Don't lump everyone in the one basket,' Trent said. `Don't treat everybody as though they are murderers and as though we have a vendetta to deal with.'

The third young man from the Riverina to lose his life in the Bali bomb blast was Shane Walsh-Till, aged 32. Shane was on holiday with his wife, Melanie, and her sister. Working as teachers in Hong Kong, Shane and Melanie had travelled to Bali for a short holiday before attending an education conference on the island. The group had been at the Sari Club when Melanie and her sister decided to go back to the motel. Minutes after their leaving, the bomb exploded. Shane had still been inside the club. The son of our Coolamon couple Bill and Barbara Till, Shane was well known in the Coolamon, Wagga Wagga and Leeton communities through his sport and his work as a teacher. He played for the Leeton-Whitton Crows Football Club and was assistant coach in 1996 and 1997. Shane was also a keen cricketer and played first grade for a number of our local clubs.

Shane taught at St Francis College of Leeton before leaving to travel and work overseas, including a teaching stint in Munich. Shane has been described by those who knew him as a great leader and an adventurous type who loved the outdoors and travelling the world. Shane's home town of Coolamon came to a standstill on Thursday morning with a service to pray for him, his family and the victims of the Bali bombing. Up to 500 people attended the service in that small community, with trucks slowing to a crawl as they passed through the town, while school children were given time off to attend the funeral of this beloved person. Businesses in the town also stopped trading, with employees in attendance at the ceremony. These young men were three gregarious, fun-loving Australians who will be dearly missed not only by their families but by their friends and the communities to which they contributed so much.

My heart goes out to all of the families who have lost loved ones. As a mother and a grandmother, there is nothing in this world more precious than my children and my family, and those families of all Australians. I would also like to acknowledge the church service at St John's Church of England at midday on Sunday in Wagga Wagga. Bishop Godfrey Friar delivered the most beautiful service, not once telling Australians of a better life, rather recognising the immense pain at this time that cannot be quelled.

I would also like to pay tribute to the team of Australian Federal Police, the Australian Security and Intelligence Organisation agents and state and territory police officers in Bali. I also thank Qantas, the Red Cross and the many agencies who have provided much needed assistance. Thanks also to the team of defence and emergency personnel who worked tirelessly to evacuate injured Australians. It is just a reminder that, despite difficulties in times of trouble, the wonderful people of Australia can unite. The efforts of many volunteers who have helped to nurse and support injured victims and their families should not go unnoticed. Many of these volunteers were holiday-makers, while others were from the local Australian community in Bali, who rushed to the scene to assist in any way they could.

All that needs to happen now for the Mavroudis, the Thompson and the Till families is for their sons and their brothers to come home. They desperately await the return of their children so they can pay them homage and know that their loved one is home with them, so that they can remember this time and put these things into perspective, and can grieve along with their family and friends in their own communities and home towns.

talk.start.para: âThe past two weeks in parliament have been unlike anything I have experienced in this place since I first arrived in 1993. Question time has been surreal. I, along with other members in this place, well remember the weekend of the Port Arthur massacre and the impact it had not only on the people of my state of Tasmania but across Australia and overseas. Unfortunately, there are many still traumatised by the events of that Sunday. On Sunday morning a week ago, many of us were enjoying the peace that is around at that time. Our day unfortunately was shattered with the breaking news of the Bali tragedy. As the day progressed and we made our way from our homes to Canberra for yet another sitting week, many of us were confronted with the realisation that possibly someone in our electorate had been involved in the tragedy. Like the Port Arthur tragedy, news was sketchy at first. As time passed and the first pictures of the tragedy flashed across our TV screens, all of us started to realise the enormity of the tragedy before us.

speech.para: I have never been to Bali but, like most if not all members of this place, I know of so many who have visited Bali year after year. These people have painted a picture of an idyllic island, free from the stresses of the worldâthe last place one would assume to bear the brunt of a terrorist attack, let alone one of such magnitude and unspeakable horror.

Over recent weeks, I have been quite vocal in the media, pursuing an antiwar policy on the issue of Iraq. I have done this from a deeply held conviction that waging war is not the answer to the world's problems. It never has been and it never will be. Most of us in this place can recollect enough of the 20th century wars to remember the human death toll in the tens of millions and the expenditure of trillions of dollars. What changed as a consequence? Empire replaced empire; the dispossessed remained the dispossessed. Albert Camus once stated:

quote.para: All I maintain is that on this earth there are pestilences and there are victims, and it is up to us, as far as possible, not to join forces with the pestilences.

speech.para: This antiwar position I hold has seen hundreds of people, from all walks of life across Australia and from overseas, email and write letters announcing their support. I have also received hate mail from those opposed to my stand. I received an envelope just last week from Melbourne addressed to `Harry Quick MP, Labor friends of Islamic terrorism'.

The unfolding tragedy in Bali is beyond our comprehension. Unless you were there, you could not possibly imagine the horror and trauma experienced by those caught up in the blast and its aftermath. I have shed tears as I watched those survivors tell of their experiences. I can only offer my heartfelt sympathy for their loss. My thoughts at this time go out to a family in my electorate, a family I have known for quite a few years. The Hawkins family of Lindisfarne, like so many others across our nation, is trying to come to grips with the realisation that one of their family members is missing, presumed killedâtheir son and brother Tim, aged 28.

As politicians, we are expected to have answers to our nation's problems, to be able to solve most of the inequities that impact upon our constituents. At a time like this, I feel helpless in the face of so much suffering and adversity. Australians at times of adversity rally around to support one another like no other nation on earth. We have seen over the past few days our medical and disaster services spring into action. We have seen the magnificent work accomplished by our armed services, especially our Air Force. The medical institutions in Darwin and subsequently in other capital cities have also responded magnificently to this greatest of challenges. I would like to add my tribute to all the workers involved in the stabilisation of the injured, those involved in the transfer of the injured back to Australia and those currently providing the best of medical services in our hospitals across the nation.

Unfortunately, at a time such as this, a time of great challenge, the bureaucratic disaster plans have been shown to be somewhat flawed. Emergency services plans for most eventualities are for those occurring on Australian soil. Now one realises that nothing like the Bali tragedy has ever been contemplated. Some changes must be made to the strategic disaster plans. The need for mobile medical teams with a broad range of specialists based in our capital cities and ready to move at very short notice should be contemplated. A far better national communication network, a disaster radio networkâperhaps appropriating ABC News Radio for the duration of the disasterâmight be considered. The coordination of services rarely usedâsuch as the need for an extraordinary amount of refrigerationâshould be part of a civil emergency plan.

I, like others in this place, would like to record my appreciation to the federal government for the many initiatives put in place to enable families to visit Bali and injured relatives in hospitals across the country. I would also like to thank the insurance industry and the various private medical funds for their enlightened response to this tragedy. I would like to express my appreciation to Qantas for its benevolent treatment of families during this tragedy, to Telstra, Optus and Vodafone for their commonsense and humane treatment of phone bills at this time. My sincere thanks to them. There is nothing more soul-destroying for families at this time than to have to argue the point over the fine print on the paperwork in dealing with their family members who were traumatised by the Bali disaster.

Like all tragedies that have affected our nation, this one has brought Australians of all walks of life closer together to share in the common grief that has impacted on so many of our communities and many of our friends and acquaintances. I hope and pray that there will be no racist retaliation in Australia because of what has happened and where it has happened. To the people of Bali who have also suffered, and will unfortunately continue to reap the whirlwind of this disaster, my thoughts, prayers and best wishes go out to them.

On Thursday in the Great Hall, we will be holding a national memorial service to allow members, senators and families to pay tribute to the memories of those killed and injured. Finally, I would like to place on the public record the fact that I despise those responsible for the tragedy in Bali, and expect that they be rightly punished for their part in this foul deed. The day 12 October 2002 will linger long in the annals of our great country as a day of infamy.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to support the Prime Minister's motion relating to the horrendous terrorist bombings in Bali last Saturday night. Words are simply not adequate to describe the grief we feel as a nation. Our hearts go out to everyone, both here and overseas, who has been affected by this senseless tragedy.

speech.para: I am not an orator and I am sure that many others in this debate will be able to put it into words much better than I can, but what I feel today is the same disbelief, numbness and worry that every Australian mother and grandmother has no doubt experienced in response to this tragedy. It is the same sort of horror that we felt on 11 September last year, only this time it has happened so close to home and to so many of our fellow countrymen and countrywomen that we realise with great clarity that we are not isolated from the evil that is terrorism. It is a very real threat to Australia and Australians; it is not something we can back away from and hope that someone else will deal with. It is our duty and responsibility as a government to do what we can to stamp out terrorism wherever it exists in the world. But I do not want to spend the short amount of time I have in this debate today talking about the perpetrators of this murderous act. Just as they displayed the very worst of humanity, this tragedy has also brought out the very best of humanity and the Australian values we all hold so dear.

Already some incredible stories of courage, mateship and sacrifice are emerging, of people with little regard for their own safety doing all they can to help others. It is this goodness, positivism and the very best of human nature that we have to hold tight in these difficult times. Rather than allowing the darkness of the magnitude of the horror to engulf us, we have to remember the values that unite us and which are so incredibly displayed at times like this.

I want to spend a few moments thanking and paying tribute to the many Australians who have helped others through this tragedy. Firstly, there are the people on the front line, so to speak, who were in Bali when the incident took place and have helped the injured, spoken with families back home, lent support and encouragement, and some who, despite sustaining injuries themselves, have been able to help with the awful task of identifying loved ones who perished. We cannot begin to imagine the pain and horror they have experienced and the emotional scars that they will no doubt carry for many years. When they return to their local communities, we have to ensure that they have the support they need to help them deal with their experiences.

I also want to sincerely acknowledge and thank the many hundreds of Australian medical staff who have been working hard to mend the terrible physical injuries suffered by so many, those on holiday in Bali who volunteered their services and those who tended to the injured on planes, in emergency units, at airports, in Darwin and in hospitals around the nation. There are simply too many people to acknowledge. Our thanks in particular go to the RAAF personnel who have been a crucial part of our early response in getting medical supplies into Bali and helping get the injured back to Australia. We have ADF specialists in a range of areas now in Bali helping with the massive task of identification and preservation of the remains of those who were murdered in this attack.

Qantas must also be thanked for their incredible response in assisting the evacuation efforts and helping the families of those still missing. Also added to the list should be Telstra, Vodafone and Optus. There are counsellors, consular staff, departmental staff and even our own electorate staff who have been talking with and attempting to assist family and friends who are frantic for news of missing loved ones. I imagine there would be very few Australians who would not be willing to do all they could to help at a time like this. I thank everyone who has played a direct part.

There are probably very few families who do not know of someone who has been affected by this tragedy. I want to send my condolences to the many families who lost loved ones, particularly those in my electorate of Forde. I was deeply saddened last Monday night to learn that friends of mine, a wonderful local couple, Marie and David Kent, lost their son David in the attack. I have known Marie for many years, and she is a great contributor to our community and a truly lovely lady. My thoughts are also with Wendy Whelan and her daughters Elisa and Melanie and son-in-law Shane Walsh-Till, Melanie's husband, who were on holidays in Bali. Sadly, Shane is still missing. I know that Wendy and her family will truly appreciate the kind words of Kay Hull, the member for Riverina. Marie, David and Wendy know that my thoughts and deepest sympathy are with them at this very difficult and very traumatic time. I share their pain and I share their deep sense of loss.

As I said at the outset, words cannot express all that we truly feel. I just urge all Australians to hold on to that very special feeling that we believe in. We must draw whatever positives we can from this senseless tragedy. In times like this the whole nation truly feels like a small community, and we can do much to support and comfort each other. Most importantly, we must all be united in our resolve to ensure that this does not diminish the unique Australian way of life that we all cherish.

I would also like to place on record my heartfelt sympathy to the peoples of Brazil, Britain, Canada, Chile, Denmark, Ecuador, France, Germany, Greece, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Portugal, South America, South Korea, Sweden, Switzerland, Taiwan and the United States. Over 120 holiday-makers from these places are dead or missing, and many more are injured. As we hurt, they also hurt. As we grieve, they also grieve. We stand united, suffering the enormous loss of our countrymen and countrywomen.

talk.start.para: âThe tragedy in Bali is almost beyond belief and Australians are right to feel not only a terrible sadness but a deep anger and a passionate hope that the perpetrators of this mass murder will be caught and brought to justice quickly. On behalf of every constituent of Calareâall of whom were spared any direct loss but nonetheless, like everybody in this country, share that lossâI pass on the deepest sympathy to the victims and the loved ones of victims of this tragedy.

speech.para: In what is a very complicated and difficult situation, some 80 Australian police and other investigators are now working in conjunction with their Indonesian counterparts. It is a painstaking task but they are making increasing inroads into the seemingly insurmountable problem of tracking down those who are responsible for this atrocity. Similarly, forensic teams are working to identify the bodies of victims so they can be brought home and laid to rest. Some, we now realise, will most likely never be identified.

There have been many stories from Bali: the sadness of the families who have lost loved ones; the heroism of the rescuers, many injured themselves, showing no hesitation to dive back into the inferno to search for friends and strangersâ

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 5.04 p.m. to 5.16 p.m.

talk.start.para: âAs I was saying, there are many stories from Bali: the sadness of the families who have lost loved ones; the heroism of rescuers, many injured themselves, showing no hesitation to dive back into the inferno to search for friends and strangers in need of a hand; the valiant efforts of the volunteers in hospitals in Bali, trained and untrained, to do what they could to keep people alive; and the tireless efforts of the medical teams, both Indonesian and Australian, to save lives. The sadness is shared by Australians, Indonesians and all the 24 nations whose citizens have been victims of this event.

speech.para: The stories of Bali capture the best of the Australian spirit. This spirit is what will enable us to deal with this tragedy without dividing our community. In expressing our grief and anger we must not risk driving a wedge between the non-Muslim and Muslim worlds in using the language of `us and them' or the `civilised world' versus the rest. We are going to need the close cooperation of predominantly Muslim nations like Indonesia and Malaysia in addressing the terrorist threat. There is a real danger in simplistically talking about Muslim terrorists because this slurs the vast majority of peace-loving Muslims who hold no truck with extremists using the Muslim faith to justify violence in the same way as Christians would condemn the extremes of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland or as Hindus would condemn the same in India.

I agree with the Prime Minister that the Bali tragedy and Iraq are two separate issues, and I was heartened to hear him confirm this. I firmly believe that no action should be taken in Iraq without UN sanction, and events in Bali certainly have not changed this opinion. What has changed after Bali is a growing realisation by Indonesia that it is going to need the support of all countries in the region, including Australia, to root out the extreme terrorism of al-Qaeda and sympathetic groups. This may well be the good that comes of this tragedyâgreater cooperation between Australia and nations to our north that may have become suspicious of our motives in East Timor and our US-UK orientation.

It is important, indeed imperative, that any response that is made to these events comes only after we have established responsibility for this act beyond question. We must avoid casting wide aspersions about it. If we become party to action that is not intelligent and directed, we risk losing control and endangering the stability of our regional relationships that have historically been quite tenuous at times. There have already been references both from politicians and in the press, particularly the American press, that this is most likely the work of al-Qaeda and sympathetic groups within Indonesia such as Jemaah Islamiah. The concurrent explosions outside the consulates of the United States and the Philippines may suggest that this indeed is the case.

Since the Bali bombings, there have been three subsequent explosions in the Philippines that have claimed more innocent lives. This should make it even more clear to us that this is a problem shared throughout our region and it will require a shared effort to defuse. Calm heads must prevail, both in this place and in the greater community. Indonesia is our closest neighbour in the region and one of the most populous countries in the world. It has seen considerable domestic political and economic turmoil since the end of Suharto's New Order regime in 1998âturmoil that had only been kept in check by the strong arm and long reach of Suharto's military power clique. It is a nation of many millions of people of many different ethnic and religious groups, despite the large Muslim majority. Tension amongst these many disparate groups has been a constant in the history of the Indonesian republic since 1945, and it continues to this date.

The attack in Bali could have been, for domestic reasons, designed to destabilise the presidency of Megawati Sukarnoputri as much as it could have been due to resentment of perceived Australian interference in Indonesia's domestic affairs, such as our peacekeeping effort in East Timor since its independence in 1999âmost justified as that was. As much again, it could be part of al-Qaeda's jihad against the West. Indeed, it could be an expression of all three. Less likely but still possible is that it could be the product of Hindu-Muslim tension and economic competition that has resulted in violence in the recent past, with transmigration of mainly Muslim Javanese to Bali's tourist based economy to escape the effects of the 1998 economic collapse.

The Parliamentary Library has provided a useful brief on possible explanations for the Bali attack and points out that violence, including bombings, have figured recently in Indonesia in attacks against bars and massage parlours in Jakarta and against the Jakarta Stock Exchange, which resulted in 10 deaths. It is possible that power cliques remaining from the New Order regime, both within and outside the military, seek to again consolidate their influence within the republic by undermining the current presidency. Similarly, it could be fundamentalist extremist groups wishing to undermine their president to facilitate their pursuit of an Islamic state.

There are many options that could explain why this tragedy has occurred. As no person or group has claimed responsibility for this act, it is all the more important that, first and foremost, we seek and find the answers. This can only be achieved to any effect, as I mentioned before, if we fully engage Indonesia on a cooperative basisâand it seems that every effort is being made to do so. In fact, I have been heartened by the statements of enthusiasm, made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs after returning from Indonesia, for what seems to be a new wave or breeze of cooperation that seems to be blowing, albeit gently, through the corridors of Jakarta.

Historically, Australia's diplomatic relationship with Indonesia has been conducted with high sensitivity. For the 30 years of the Suharto regime, this manifested itself in our de jure recognition of its occupation of East Timor for almost 25 yearsâuntil this government's initiativeâand the convenient ignoring of other human rights abuses across the archipelago. The importance of a good and strong relationship with Indonesia was always afforded priority over these issues. Perhaps now we can follow the strong relationship with a clearer conscience, but we should never allow it to overshadow increasing concerns over West Papua. The price of a cooperative, shared investigation, intelligence and action on terrorism should not be either an assault on our own domestic human rights or a blind eye to oppression in West Papua or elsewhere.

Like us, the vast majority of the Indonesian population want nothing to do with extreme fundamentalism and terrorism; they too want peace and stability. We have an opportunity here to engage our closest neighbour in this extremely important effort, standing and acting on our own terms, embracing the region in which we live. This could be the emotional link between our two countries, as Paul Sheehan said in the Sydney Morning Herald, which has been missing from the relationship in the past 50-odd years.

The events in Bali deserve a focused effort by our government and its agencies to dissolve the threat of terrorism in our region as a priority over tailing the interests of other nations elsewhere in the world. Our great and powerful friends exhort us to support their efforts internationally against terrorism. We can do this, but we can do it best in our own region on a cooperative basis with our neighbours, especially those nations of majority Muslim faith. Our allies must recognise and support us in this decision, as they have supported Australia's previous efforts to make peace in our neighbourhood. Now is the time to qualify and carefully direct our support for the international effort against terrorism. We find ourselves with an unprecedented opportunity to build stronger, more useful and peaceful relationships within our region. If we do not make this cooperative approach a priority then we risk great damage to those relationships.

Beyond that, we and other Western nations must examine our own policies of imposing economic and social values on the non-Christian and on the Third World, for many of those policies when inappropriately and insensitively applied are easily exploitable by fanatics and haters of the West. Such policies find ready converts in the impressionable youth of a Peshawar border camp, in Islamic fundamentalist schoolsâno different in essence to an IRA campâin disaffected Saudis angry at American military presence on their soil, in West Bank Palestinians or, indeed, among the economically marginalised of Indonesia.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the motion moved in the House of Representatives by the Prime Minister on 14 October, immediately after the terrorist attacks in Bali. No doubt our days of mourning will be many and we will swing from deep anger to unbearable sadness. That has certainly already been evident in the community. For a long time we will ask why this would happen to so many young, innocent Australians and people from many parts of the world. The attack was murderous and cowardly and the perpetrators are people who hide themselves from the world. Their attacks, wherever they take place, come without warning and are indiscriminateâkilling and maiming innocent men, women and children. Such attacks are to be utterly condemned.

speech.para: The personal heartache and pain this insane act has caused can have no justification whatsoever. In talking about the heartache and pain, one young man, Jason Stokes, the assistant coach of the Kingsley football team, is still not accounted for. His parents and friends are amongst those who face the agonising wait because Jason is not accounted for. My heart aches for his distraught parents and his friends. His parents live in my electorate of Pearce. I have to say, as a mother and a grandmother, that there would be nothing that would concern me more than to be left uncertain about the fate of one of my children, my grandchildren or indeed any member of my family.

We can speculate on why these people have perpetrated such atrocious acts on innocent people, but I think at the heart of it these attacks appear to be directed towards anyone who is not a believer of the extreme religious views of the perpetrators. No-one in any part of the world who does not embrace these extreme religious views will be safe from attacks in the future. The perpetrators are not people who are driven by poverty or oppression; they are extremists with a mission to try to create terror in civil societies.

Thoughts that Australian people can escape such attacks by remaining silent are seriously misplaced. We can never allow ourselves to be cowed by such acts of brutality. The courage of Australian people in the face of threats and bullying has always been legendary, and I have every confidence that we will stand firm and resolute in the face of this dreadful event. We will work tirelessly to see those responsible for this atrocity brought to justice in a system that undoubtedly will treat them more humanely than the perpetrators treated the innocent victims of their cowardly attacks.

By contrast we have seen, as we have heard today and in other speeches over the last few days, that there have been many courageous acts both during and after the bombings. Every day there are new reports of people having rescued their friends from burning buildings and putting their own lives at risk. We have heard stories of the assistance given by medical professionals, the Defence Force, department of foreign affairs staff, emergency services and Red Crossâthe list of people assisting has been endless. They have worked in the most difficult circumstances to help the injured. Ordinary people on holiday have inspired us with their generosity and their willingness to volunteer their time to help.

Australian people are tolerant and peace loving. It is very heartening to see the nation come together to show such caring for one another, and with such generosity of spirit. To mourn together, to comfort those who have lost family members and friends, and to generously offer financial assistance where it is needed: these, to my way of thinking, are the hallmarks of a civil society. These are the things that Australian people stand up for and these are the qualities that make Australia a place that we all feel very privileged to live in.

I will conclude because I feel that to go on would be only to repeat the many wonderful speeches that we have heard and many of the points that have been raised. I extend my sympathy not only to the parents of Jason Stokes who live in the electorate of Pearce but also to everyoneâthe Balinese, all Australians and the many people from many parts of the world who have lost family members and/or friends. My thoughts and prayers also go out to those who have come back to Australia with serious injuries and are still in hospital. I wish them a speedy recovery, as I am sure we all do.

talk.start.para: âI would also like to add my condolences and concerns to the many others that have already been given in this House. Obviously all of us have shared in the devastation over the last few days and on behalf of the people in my electorate, who I think would like to have recorded in this place their condolences, I send sympathy and support to the family and friends who have lost loved ones in this tragedy. We are now a little further down the track, a few more days have passed since this terrible act, but the trauma and tragedy of the event is going to stay with the survivors for the rest of their lives. We know that many of these survivors will be emotionally and physically scarred from this event and haunted by it for many years to come.

speech.para: My thoughts certainly go to those survivors and particularly to the families and friends who are still waiting for news about those who are unaccounted for. As the days go by more people are sure of the fate of their loved ones, but still do not have any confirmation that that has been the case. This is a terrible time for those families as well. Not knowing the fate of their loved ones and waiting for the news can be almost the most unbearable part of this process for family and friends. My heart goes out to those people waiting for news and confirmation and some sort of finality.

We have the immediate grief of the tragedy, but much of this grief is going to be felt for many years. Obviously life will never be the same for the family and friends who have lost their loved ones in these bombings. Even for those of us not directly touched by family or friends having been involved, we too have felt the impact and their pain. I must say that reading the paper and watching TV, although I am not prone to crying in movies and those sorts of things, I felt that my heart was in my throat. I was very tearful at the scale of the human tragedy that we were talking about and the nearness of it to all of us. That has affected all of us, from the oldest and most experienced to the newest members of this House, in a way that we would never have expected. That comes with the acute awareness that it could easily have been any one of us, our family or our friends, on a holiday escape.

I would like to say that, unlike some of my colleagues from Western Australia who I know have had whole football teams and communities drastically affected by this sad event, we too in my electorate have had one person who was not identified initially and was recently added to the list of missing persons. My electorate would like to have recorded in this House our sympathy and concern for Ms Sylvia Dalais, 55, who is feared to have become one of the latest victims in the terrorist strike. As I say, her name was not originally on the list and we have not yet been able to contact family members who no longer live in my electorate. Certainly from the newspaper reports, her son was very aware that the Sari nightclub was a place that his mother was very fond of attending, enjoying dancing and living life, and the things that so many others who were caught up in this enjoyed. Again, on behalf of the electorate, we would like to record our sympathy and condolences for Ms Dalais and her family at this very difficult time.

Many of us are asking as well, `How are we going to ever regain our confidence and trust in the carefree travel that so many people were involved in when they were in Bali?' This came home to us particularly clearly because there were so many young people involved enjoying themselves at the Sari Club in Bali, experiencing a new culture, dancing, socialising and generally living it upâall of the things that for a long time we have encouraged our young people to do. Overseas travel for young Australians has been almost a rite of passage and, for many of our young Australians, Bali has been the favoured destination for them testing the water, if you like, being the first trip that they might make overseas to see what international travel is like. For many, it has been the first step to opening our eyes and minds to all types of new experiences. By attacking this destination, the perpetrators of this awful act of murder have really purposely struck at the core of our sense of freedom and fun. The intention is clearly to make us fearful of travel, of enjoying ourselves and of challenging ourselves by moving beyond our day-to-day comfort zones to try something new. The intention, as many others have said before me, was for us to be worried and afraid. In recent days since the bombings, it is hard to feel that they are not going to get their way. This event has scared a great many people. I met with a number of mental health experts who work particularly with young people, who have warned that this tragedy in Bali may have even more impact on Australian teenagers and young people than, for example, the attack on the World Trade Centre because Bali was a place where young people, and particularly young Australians, gathered to relax and enjoy life.

Obviously the images alone of the events that we have seen can have an enormous impact on the mental health and wellbeing of many of our children and young people. The Mental Health Council of Australia has warned that children, in particular, are very vulnerable to these graphic images and must be protected from that trauma. We must protect ourselves from the trauma as best we can, not because we want to ignore what has happened but because we need to ensure that everyone can see a way beyond this and have some reason to trust in our future. I believe it is a time when we must all take care to remind each other of the good things in life, of the advantages of living in a country like ours and of the opportunities that we will have in the future for much more fun, care and love with other friends and families.

We must not let terrorists have their way by turning us into people who fear to enjoy life, to travel, to be adventurers. I know that it is hard in the midst of this tragedy and sufferingâand there is still much that is unknown for many peopleâto imagine what it will be like to go beyond this as a nation, but we must. Particularly, I would like to urge that we must not lose sight of this for our young people. That generation has largely been blissfully free of war experience. They have grown up excited, feeling that the world is their oyster, that there are challenges before them and that they will not be hindered by the sorts of things that generations before them went through during the two world wars.

So we want our young people to continue to set off to discover their own place in the world and to see other parts of the world. We want our footy teams to have a chance to relax after a demanding season. We want newlyweds to feel comfortable to walk hand in hand along the beach. I think if we lose the chance of doing that, whether it is in Bali or elsewhere, then we will be giving the perpetrators of this atrocity the satisfaction that they have done much more than kill and injure many hundreds of peopleâthey will have stolen our freedom to enjoy life.

In the short time that is left, I want to also acknowledge that there are many people who live in my electorate who have had the misfortune of facing the tragedies of war, conflict and terrorism in their mother countries before they came to Australia. They came here to find peace and make a new life, and many of them fight to overcome the demons in their memories. I hope that this does not reawaken those horrors for them and, in fact, that we may look to them for assistance and the lessons in how to overcome past fears and horrors and to get on and make a new and positive life. I hope that, in the same way that the new immigrants have been able to adopt our carefree and open society, peace and security will also eventually be able to be found for those people directly affected by this terrible act.

I would like to finish by reminding people, as others have as well, that we should remember that the place where this atrocity occurred was also a place of work for many Balinese people who were also killed. I think that in this House we all agree that no-one should have to put their life at risk by turning up to work. For the Balinese, this workplace was set up to provide pleasure and enjoyment, primarily for Australians, and for working in such a place many locals have paid a very high price. Our sympathies should go to those local people who were killed and injured and to their families as well.

I also, along with others, want to record my thanks to the doctors, nurses, volunteers and those other family members and friends faced with the grim task of identifying bodies and sorting through the rubble, both human and other, to try and provide certainty to family members and friends. These too are experiences that no-one ever could expect or want to be part of, but many people have unquestioningly sprung to immediate action to help others in need, and I think they deserve our heartfelt thanks and, indeed, support for the trauma that they too have suffered.

I trust that every effort will be made to find the perpetrators of this vile crime and bring them to justice, and I think that it has brought home to us that we cannot ignore the fact that we have a role to play at an international level in trying to work for these positive solutions. Of course we need to develop strategies that combat the environment where extremism thrives. These environments are those of systemic poverty, injustice, racial intolerance and persecution based on race, religion or political views. As a country, we must now take up the challenge and take our place in the international community to be part of the solution and not part of the problem.

talk.start.para: âI mourn the innocent victims of the terrorist bombings in Bali on Saturday, 12 October 2002 and condemn the perpetrators of that attack. I wish to support the Prime Minister's motion and the words of those who have spoken before me and spoken very well, as my predecessor has. I would like to extend my deep sympathy to those Australians who have been touched by this dreadful event: to the families and friends of those who were killed in the bombing who have lost loved ones in this most deplorable and indiscriminate way; to those who have suffered injury and psychological trauma as a result of the bombings, and their families and friends who have waited through extreme anxiety to see whether they were alive or not; and to the Australian people who have felt the suffering of their fellow citizens. We can only inadequately imagine the anguish of those who are still waiting and hoping for any news of their family and friends, or for the forensic identification process to be completed so that they can reclaim and bury the bodies.

speech.para: They all should know that throughout this nation and in this chamber there is a deep sympathy and sadness for their loss and a great anger at those who caused it. The immense pain of and the support for the grief stricken were manifest on Sunday, our national day of mourning. This multicultural country came together to commemorate our personal and national losses and the losses of the international community, and we did so in a myriad ways and placesâon football fields and beaches, in gardens and churches and in mosques. I hope that those who have been so terribly devastated by the bombings in Bali derive some comfort and strength from this very visible demonstration of unity and sympathy. The grief and trauma will not be diminished for some time, but neither will the sympathy and community support.

All of us, as parliamentarians, feel a great sadness about the harm visited upon so many people by the atrocity in Bali, and I think we feel this most keenly where people from our own constituency have been killed or are missing. Sadly, a member of the Kooyong community, Bronwyn Cartwright, is still missing, and my particular sympathies go to her family and friends.

Our strongest empathy is always with the people in our own community and in our own nationâthose who were affected by such dreadful eventsâand that is natural. But we also feel great sadness for the citizens of other nations who were killed or injured in these outrageous attacksâcitizens of New Zealand, Germany, Britain, France, Belgium, the United States and many others. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to them too and to their families and friends. We also feel immense sorrow for the people of Indonesia and, in particular, for the many people of Bali who were killed or injured and for their families and friends. The suffering in the local community where this atrocity took place will linger in many ways for years to come.

But out of the carnage of Bali have also come acts of memorable heroism, bravery and selflessness. We have heard remarkable tales of people risking their own lives to try to save the lives of others who were caught in the bombing. They are to be admired and commended.

As the rescue and recovery effort has gone on, we have also seen great heroism in people who would probably say that they were just doing their job. It is important to recognise these people as wellâto recognise the medical workers across Australia who have continued to treat shocking injuries under extraordinary circumstances; the many counsellors who are now trying to assist those traumatised by these events; and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade officers, the Australian Defence Force, and the police and security servicesâall of whom have played an important part in managing the crisis situation we have witnessed over the past week or so. Australian businesses and individuals also deserve appreciation for the efforts they have already made to do what they can to helpâfrom making special travel arrangements and concessions to travel conditions to the rush to donate blood.

Australia has been on a heightened state of alert since September 11 last year, but it still does come as an enormous shock when a terrorist attack of this scale and character occurs. The fact that Australians number so significantly amongst the casualties, together with the happy associations and the memories that so many Australians have of Bali, does sharply bring the reality of terrorist threats another step closer. But, as I have said in this place before, terrorism's potential to inflict mass casualties has long been apparent, and democratic leaders have consistently emphasised the potential for major casualties from terrorist action. The targeting of the World Trade Centre last year was a massive attack on a purely civilian target. But the United States, and indeed the World Trade Centre itself, had been the targets of terrorists before.

The reality now is that our part of the world has increasingly emerged as a terrorist target, and it is the responsibility of each nation to meet the threat of terrorism. This is not just a responsibility to its own citizens. It is a responsibility which each nation has to its neighbours and to all nations in the region. It is a responsibility which all countries have to the peoples of all nations that make up the civilised international community. There have been serious questions raised about Indonesia's preparedness and capacity to confront the terrorist challenge in the region. I think it is encouraging to read the comments of Indonesian officials and to witness their actions in the past week and the capacity of their government to take firm action to combat terrorism, increase security and confront terrorist threats in the region and in their area.

The members of the Australian parliament on all sides, regardless of their political commitments, are outraged at the barbaric terrorist attacks that took place in Bali 10 days ago. The members of the Australian community, regardless of race and religion, condemn those who employ terror and indiscriminate violence against innocent people. This parliament and our country will do everything in our power to bring to justice those who are responsible for this outrage, and we expect our friends and allies to contribute to this. We must respond to this attack in a measured, proportionate and effective way to seek to prevent this sort of tragedy being inflicted again.

talk.start.para: âI first heard the news of the Bali bombing as our household was waking up to its usual Sunday morning routine. It was a sunny and normalâand I say `normal' in inverted commasâmorning in Melbourne and somehow the clamour and excitement in our house could not absorb the initial horror of the news. It has been 10 days since it occurred and it still is difficult to comprehend not only the unspeakable grief but also the realisation of what this means for us now and its potential consequences.

speech.para: Like every Australian, my thoughts have been with the families of the people whose lives were so brutally ended. As a parent, I feel great sympathy and anguish for those other parents who have lost their children. I, like everyone else, adore my kidsâas we all doâand there is no greater fear for any parent than the fear that something will happen to their children. This fear has been so poignantly expressed time and time again during these last few days, but its vulnerability resonates most in the words of one mother who, after clasping her son in her arms, said, `I'll never let him go away again.'

I have watched the television screen on a daily basis feeling sadness for all those parents, relatives and friends who have spent the last week at airports around the country waiting for their loved ones to arrive. We feel even greater sadness now for those who must wait for the repatriation of the remains of their loved ones. We have heard so many of them tell their story that we now feel we know them personally. Their stories are painful, and I have been particularly inspired by the young mother who was driven to safety by the image of her seven-year-old son and the thought that she could not leave him without a mother. Craig Salvatori's story and his agony have also touched me profoundly, having to tell his little girls that their mummy has gone to heaven and having to endure the frustration in his attempt to identify his wife's body. That is how all of us in our own way relate personally to our fellow Australians. It could have been any one of us, it could be any one of usâand we ask ourselves, `Why?'

Sadly, 12 October 2002 will be another one of those defining moments for Australiaâa day when a tragedy beyond our comprehension took place. We were not at war and this was not a natural disaster. The scene was a regular Saturday night in a local nightclub at a popular holiday destination. The victims were young people on holiday, just having a good time. They hurt no-one; they provoked no-one. They were not players in world affairs. They were just part of a happy crowd, minding their own businessâand within seconds they were blown away. There was no warning, no reason; they were just unlucky to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. In a matter of seconds, their lives and their families' lives were altered forever.

As a nation, we are left to face the harsh reality that we are vulnerable. But the way Australians have come together to collectively share the grief is commendable. It makes me proud to be an Australian, and I know that this will make us stronger. I want to stop short of saying, however, that our days of innocence are over. To believe or accept that would severely restrict the freedoms with which we are lucky enough to live our lives in this country. Despite the tragedy of what happened last weekend in Bali, I know that none of us would want to surrender those freedoms, especially our freedom of movement.

We must not be spooked by the bastardry and hatred for other people which drives those who we have now come to know as terrorists and leads to callous killings. Their actions are indiscriminate and spare no-one. They can be vanquished, and I am certain that we have the spirit and the strength to act with reason and wisdom despite our hurt and anger. To the families who have lost their loved ones, all I can say is that your grief is felt by all and that we are united in our efforts to find the perpetrators and bring them to justice.

Last Sunday, the day after the bombings, I went to the peace rally in the city of Melbourne. I was moved by the many young people who were there. However, I kept thinking of the tragedy in Bali; so were the people beside me in the street; so was everyone I spoke to or walked withâall horrified, all devastated. I marched under the banner of the Islamic Council of Victoria. Many of the people there were my constituents. They too felt devastation. They denounced the bombing in the same way as the rest of us, but they also expressed their own fears and concerns. Since September 11 they too have felt vulnerable, but more so than the rest of us. They feel vulnerable in their own backyards, in their streets and in their neighbourhoods. Their children feel vulnerable at school. Many of them felt sick to the stomach in anticipation of a backlash, which has already occurred in two separate incidences in both Melbourne and Sydney. They too are Australians and in this difficult time they also feel under siege. But they also feel that their loyalty to Australia is constantly challenged. Their sentiments areâand I am sure they want me to convey this to the parliamentâthat not in the name of Islam does anyone have the right to perpetrate such murder against innocent people.

In conclusion, I just wanted to say that despite what we feel at the momentâour anger at this senseless loss of lifeâwe must also remain measured, because it is understandable that the enormity of our emotions in the short term will demand revenge. That is a human reaction but it is important that we remain measured. It is comforting to know that others are also calling for reason. We want answers but I am also heartened by the many people who do not seek violence as a means of revenge. This is what makes me proud to be an Australian. I love our decency, our mateship and our courage and I am proud of the way we have come together as a nation to share our grief.

Many opinion makers, however, have already sought to pass judgment by accusing those who in recent times have expressed a different view from their own as being cowards, and they talk of appeasers. Already, vilification of the so-called left wing has been in progress. Already many are seeking to use this incident to shore up their cause for Australian involvement in a war against Iraq and to say, `I told you so,' and to warn that unless we participate in this war we will never be safe again. That may be the case but that may also not be the case. The bombing of the Sari nightclub and the subsequent deaths of innocent people should not be a reason for us to surrender our freedom of movement. Equally, it should not be used as a reason for some to challenge our freedom of speech.

Our nation is built on strong democratic principles and the rule of law. We cherish our right to our opinion and we expect that opinion to be considered on an equal basis to the opinions of others which may be different. Australians have always spoken their mind, and for those 50,000 people in Melbourne on Sunday who marched against war their opinions should be accorded the same respect as the opinions of those who support war. Those people should not be accused of being unpatriotic or made to feel that they cannot express their views in case they are seen to be unsympathetic. This is not a time for one opinion to seek vantage over another.

talk.start.para: âI would like to briefly add my comments to this motion of grief. I have nothing new to say that has not already been said but, as a member of this parliament and as a member of a nation that is still shocked and grieving and angry, I want to join in recording my empathy with my fellow countrymen.

speech.para: In doing so, I want to say three things. Firstly, I want to express my genuine sympathy to all who are suffering, to those who are grieving the loss of loved onesâfamily, lovers, friends and mates of the perhaps 180 dead. Possibly up to 92 Australians died, mostly young people, along with people from 20 countries around the world, including from Bali and other parts of Indonesia. All were innocent victims of this callous and evil act. Secondly, I want to extend my sympathy to those battling the agony of uncertaintyâthose whose loved ones are still among the 62 or so still missing, fearing the worst yet hoping beyond hope that their worst fears may not be realised. Thirdly, I want to assure those, perhaps over a hundred people, who are suffering horrific unimaginable injuries that our thoughts are also with them at this terrible time of suffering.

In addition, I would like to join others around Australia and around the world in utterly condemning this outrageous act of brutality and barbarism. It is unfathomable that people could act in such a despicable, inhuman way to so callously inflict such suffering on innocent people. It defies belief that anyone could wilfully visit such evil on others. No ideology, no cause, no level of extremism can come close to justifying such an act of inhumanity.

Finally, I want to declare my support for the determination of the Australian government and other decent peace-loving governments around the world in their stand against terror and in their commitment to bring to justice the perpetrators of this foul deed. There are some who would naively argue against taking such a stand. They erroneously argue that refusing to do so would somehow shield us from any future attack. The fact is that the current terrorist scourge born out of anti-Western, antidemocratic extremism has absolutely no respect for persons and we would remain a target, regardless of how we respond. The only hope is for those who embrace freedom to stand strongly together against terrorism, to root out those responsible and to bring them to justice. Words are hopelessly inadequate at a time like this. They cannot possibly relieve the pain of those who are grieving. Yet, like all Australians, we want them to know that we stand with them at this terrible time of loss.

talk.start.para: (Mr Barresi)âI call the member for Burke and thank him.

âIt has already been said by many speakers who have spoken on this motion how dreadful the events of 10 days ago were for the country at large. Clearly, the tragedy is resonating throughout the country. I, as the member for Burke, on Sunday happened to be involved in two services. The first was in Bacchus Marsh, where I presided over an ecumenical service which involved the Mayor of Moorabool, Mr Allan Comrie; the member for Melton, Mr Don Nardella; pastors of many denominations; and the Mayor of Melton, Sophie Ramsay. Most importantly, the service was filled with hundreds of locals from Bacchus Marsh, all there to lay a single flower to commemorate those most affected by this dreadful tragedy. The sympathy was palpable. Most of the speeches were sombre and short, and they focused upon the victims.

speech.para: The national day of mourning that was recommended by the Leader of the Opposition and welcomed formally by the Prime Minister allowed communities across Australiaânot just in the capital cities but in communities beyondâto commemorate the victims and the dead, and to reflect upon the awful suffering endured by the families. As was said earlier by the member for Gellibrand, it was an opportunity to reflect upon the aching pain that must be experienced now by the loved ones and families of those missingâthose victims, it would appear, whose fate has yet to be confirmed.

It is very hard, whether it be at a service or elsewhere, or even on my feet now in the parliament, to really find the right words to comfort people at the local level or, indeed, comfort people of the nation, but one of our functions is to take that role. The other service I was involved in was again an ecumenical service at a Baptist church in Sunbury, which also involved other local representatives, including the member for Gisborne, Joanne Duncan, and the mayor of the council. The congregation came from all different denominations. It was a great testimony to the fact that, when such national crises as these occur, people's differences seem to fall away and we are left with what we hold in common. What we hold in common is not just a love for this country, its institutions and its capacity to disagree democratically, but also a strong bond which has been reflected since this awful day.

It is also fair to note, now 10 days on, that as the days continue there is a need at some point for us to consider and, can I say, to analyse what causes these things. It will be important for this parliament to properly contemplate the causes of these dreadful acts. We normally refer to them as senseless acts and acts with no reason, but we must find reason. They can never be excused; they can never be rationalised as being acceptable. They are barbaric acts. But we must find causes so we can prevent future acts like this. I therefore agree with the member for Calwell, when she said that we must not allow acts like this to cause this country to turn in on itself. It is a difficult balance. On the one hand, we want to make sure we find the perpetrators of such events. We want to bring them to justice, but we also want to protect the things the terrorists want to destroy, other than the victims that are the most clearly obvious focus of their hatred. They also want us to attack our institutions, to attack our civil liberties and to attack our freedoms. It would be paradoxical if we found ourselves attacking, or allowing terrorists to have us undermine, our own democratic principles in this way. That is something for this parliament and the community at large to consider in future. I do think it is important that we reflect upon those things. But today, for me, is a time, as it was on Sunday, to consider fully the effects on the victims. We can only guess how hard it would be.

There are just two instances in my electorate. I am glad to say that there is no confirmation of anybody being a victimâand, by definition, I mean any deceased or injured person or any person that I have been made aware of that is related to any victim. However, many members of the local football club in Lancefield were in Bali and were 400 metres from the blast. They were witness to the aftermath of those explosions and were stranded in Bali. Their families did not know their fate until some time after. Therefore, for them and their families, what an amazing and overwhelming sense of relief it must have been to realise that they were able to avoid this tragedy in a direct sense.

I hope they were not witness to the aftermath in a direct sense, because I think if we are going to define `victim' here then we have to define `victim' to include not only those who were physically injured as result of the explosions but also those who may be affected psychologically as witnesses to either the event itself or the consequences of the event. I have not yet been able to speak to the Lancefield Football Club members who were in Bali, but I hope I will do so soon. My office has certainly spoken to the club itself.

The other local instance I wanted to raise was that I spoke to a mother whose daughter was in the Sari Club at the time of the explosions, and she expressed to me her overwhelming relief that there, but for the grace of God, goes her daughter, in effect. Her daughter was in the club and managed to get out without physical injury. However, who knows the extent to which she will suffer as a result of this tragedy.

In conclusion, it was very important that on Sunday we commemorated the dead, the injured and the families. I think this parliament will have to consider in more analytical terms in the future how we are to avoid conflicts such as this and whether there are ways in which we can mitigate the potential of these things happening in the region and, indeed, around the world because, until we find the root cause of terrorism, we will not feel fully safe and we will not have done our job as leaders of the community.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr ANTHONY
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âI am honoured to be able to speak to this motion in relation to the terrible attacks in Bali. Indeed, on the national day of mourning I was in my own church in Murwillumbah and had to speak to the congregation, like many members of parliament and many others around the country. I was certainly filled with mixed emotions. It was in this particular church where I got married, yet here we were in this church on such a sad day for the people of our valley and our nation, mourning the loss of so many young Australians who lost their lives through their own innocence and through a callous, brutal act by a terrorist organisation. The lives of over 180 individuals from many different nationalities around the world were cut shortâthe vast majority of those being Australian citizens.

speech.para: My heart goes out to all the parents and to all the children of those who were killed, to their loved ones, to their friends, to their relations and to the communities where so many young Australians are now not coming back from their holidays. Two cases in particular have affected my local area. Barry Wallace and his daughter, Julieâwho I think postponed her trip to go to Bali due to September 11 last yearâwent to Bali for relaxation and enjoyment. Her life was cut short and her body is still to be identified. The sheer pain and anguish of Barry and his family and his ex-wife and others who new Julie must be awful at the moment.

Another family close to home are also going through that pain and anguish, and that is the Hardy family of Tweed Heads. Billy Hardy is still missing. Billy went to Bali with a group of football players from the Southport Sharks and he has not returned home. His family and all those associated with Billy are grieving terribly at the moment for the loss of life and the inability at the moment to identify their loved ones.

This story is being replayed in many parts of Australia. Our belief in freedom and in the freedom of our nation was suddenly shattered on the night of 12 October in the Sari nightclub. Indeed, the fight for freedom is the constant fight that all Western countries have, particularly Australia, as we join forces with other nations in the fight against terrorism. The fight against terrorism is a fight for freedom of the values that we respect and honour, and we must never bow down to the pressure of these evil, callous individuals or organisations who are deliberately going out of their way to attack innocent civilian people in a campaign of terror.

I noticed that, in the speeches that were made by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives on the Monday after this tragic incident, the constant theme was that we must continue to be ever vigilantâ like the RSL motto: the price of liberty is eternal vigilance. Many Australian citizens have paid an enormous price because of these terrorist organisations. Many of the citizens of my electorate and many citizens of Australia have great concerns about the potential dissemination of these terrorist groups within the country of our nearest neighbourâIndonesia. As a nation, we need to maintain and strengthen our dialogue with the Indonesian leadership and give them the support to pursue those who are responsible for this dastardly deed. We need to offer support to our Australian institutions, right through to our ADF, to ensure that the fabric of Indonesia is preserved in the sense that those authorities pursue these people and there is not seen to be a complacency towards pursuing any terrorist organisation within this country.

The issues are far greater than the tragedy that occurred on 12 October. It is a wider campaign, and Australia must continue to take up the cudgels in the fight against terrorism and those countries that support terrorism. To this end, I think all Australians would recognise that there is still an urgent need to pursue those nations and those individuals who are harbouring terrorists, particularly those who may have the potential to use weapons of mass destruction. One can only imagine what would happen if these individuals, with their total disregard for human rights, were able to obtain biological, chemical or nuclear weapons. They would use these weapons with devastating impactâjust as devastating as the impact experienced in our own nation and other nations by the events in Bali.

Families have been shattered by the events of 12 October and their lives will forever be changed. My deepest sympathies go to those families and victims. It is entirely appropriate that we as a national parliament honour them as much as we can this Thursday when some of the relatives come to the nation's capital and to our parliament. Individuals and communities, particularly all the emergency service workers and hospital staff, have been working around the clock to care and cater for those who were terribly injured in the bomb blasts. We hope that they make a full recovery, although they will always have to endure the scarsâas previous speakers have mentioned. Even those people who had minimal injuries will experience psychological hurt and the hurt to their hearts will stay with them forever.

As I mentioned before, the fight against terrorism must be unrelenting. We must be for ever vigilant, just as the RSL motto states. With absolutely steely determination and dedication, we must continue to pursue the evil people who perpetrated this deed and bring them to justice. More importantly, we must be ever vigilant in securing our internal security. We hope this does not spread to us, but no-one knows that.
