If we are to really succeed in reducing the frequency of terrorist acts of this kind, we also must explore how people can come to view their fellow human beings as instruments of their campaigns, as disposable; in other words, as having no value. How can they come to regard life as so easily set aside?

In this so-called global war on terrorism, it is important to ask first exactly what we mean by terrorism. The usual definition goes something like `the use or threat of violence by small groups against non-combatants of large groups for avowed political goals'. Terrorism, as one analyst put it, is the warfare of the weak, the recourse of those desperate for a cause that they cannot win by conventional means. We should also remember that state terrorism against a state's own citizensâas practised by Mao, Stalin, Hitler, Pol Pot and a smaller league of tyrantsâhas also killed many millions of non-combatants. And, of course, wars everywhere now kill more civilians than soldiers.

As I pointed out earlier, the only way some of us can bear to contemplate acts of terror such as those that killed our fellow citizens in Bali, the people of Bali and those of other lands, is to conclude that there must be something fundamentally wrong with the terrorists. They must be crazy, suicidal or psychopaths without moral feelings or indeed any feelings for others. Unfortunately, this is too easy. Many years of research reveal that psychopathology and personality disorder is no more likely amongst terrorists than among non-terrorists from the same background. It is easy to call them crazy. It allows us to escape proper analysis. It adds nothing to our understanding of their behaviour, or of those who might do the same thing in the future, to call them crazy or evil. Rather we have to face the factâand this is a very hard fact to faceâthat normal people can be terrorists, that in some cases perhaps we are ourselves capable of terrorist acts.

This fact is already implied in recognising that military and police forces in some dictatorships, past and present, have been and are eminently capable of killing non-combatants. They were in Nazi Germany; they were in Kosovo. Some of you will have read the excellent work called Hitler's Willing Executioners. How did ordinary people come to be so vile and so brutal? No-one wakes up one morning and decides today is the day to become a terrorist. The path by which otherwise normal people become capable of doing terrible things is usually gradual, perhaps imperceptible to everyone including the individual. The process is well described by Horowitz in The Deadly Ethnic Riot. Terrorists, we have to acknowledge, kill for the same reasons that groups have killed each other for centuries. They kill, as one writer put it, for cause and comrades, a combination of ideology and intense group dynamics.

The group values represented in the cause are often focused with an intensity that we could not begin to understand, with a group of like-minded people who are prepared to perpetrate terrorist violence. Members of a terrorist group put the group first, above all others, dropping every other connection with their communities, often with their families and their friends, isolating themselves. The power of the group becomes enormous and it extends to every personal and moral judgment. In that sense, they do become warped. This power can make violence against what they perceive as the enemy not just acceptable but necessary. It has to be said that even armies cut trainees off from their previous lives so that the combat unit can become their family. These processes are not abnormal, they are normal, and we should recognise that they occur daily around us. That is not to excuse the process but rather to try and use our intelligence to understand it. In brief, the psychology behind terrorist violence is normal psychology, abnormal only in the intensity of the group dynamics that link cause with comrades and that allow violence of the kind that we have seen.

Terrorism is designed to inflict immediate damage in destroying lives and material, but terrorists hope of course that the long-term cost will be much greater. They want to create fear and uncertainty, far beyond the victims and those close to themâthe people whose lives we are mourning today. They want the people they perceive as their enemy to spend time and money on security; they want to lay, in effect, an enormous tax on every aspect of the enemy's society, a tax that transfers resources from productive and creative purposes to antiproductive security measures. That is something to which we must be very alert.

In particular, terrorists hope, indeed they wish devoutly, that they will elicit a violent response that will assist them in mobilising people who are not yet engaged. A terrorist group is at the top of a pyramid of supporters and sympathisers. The base of the pyramid is composed of all those who sympathise with the terrorist cause even though they may disagree with the violent means. We have seen this in many casesâin Northern Ireland, for instance, where the base of the pyramid might be said to be those who agree with the slogan `Brits out', as they did in the seventies and eighties, who would not themselves use violence but provided a seedbed for the terrorists. In the Islamic world, the base of the pyramid is all those who think that they have been hurt and humiliated over the years. They would not themselves use violence, but the terrorists hope to mobilise them. The nature of our response may or may not succeed in doing that.

Terrorists hope generally that a clumsy and over-generalised strike against them will turn those sympathetic but immobilised people to action and sacrifice, and strengthen their own status at the apex of that pyramid. We have seen that happen over past decades. They also hope for a reaction of stereotyping and prejudice so that more people will identify with them, that they will be seen not just as a tiny extremist splinter group but as representative of a whole group of people. They are tendencies that we must resist at any price. The reaction of stereotyping and prejudice against Arabs and Muslims will turn themâif we overreact globally by stereotyping all of themâfrom sources of help, the moderates particularly, against terrorism to sources of further terrorism.

Since the bombing of the World Trade Centre and now since the bombing in Bali much of the global response to terrorism has shifted from criminal justiceâfinding, trying and punishing perpetratorsâto the idea of waging war. I think this has consequences. Framing terrorism and the response to terrorism implies a movement from individual blame to group blame. I think that is a mistake. The terrorists are not numerous, they may be widespread and they may be brutal and dangerous, but to the extent that we assume that they are representative, we are giving them a great deal more power than they deserve.

We should ensure that we find every one of the murderers who killed our fellow citizens and that we try to do everything we can to prevent others joining them. A shift to the rhetoric of war, I think, signals the possibility of recruiting more people to their causes and I, for one, would certainly not want to see that happen. I do not want to see more people like Jane and Jenny Corteen die in a place like Bali, a place of recreation.

We must use our intelligence to understand these matters. We must use our intelligence and all our diligence to find the perpetrators. We must actively wage campaigns against the people who would join these terrorists and argue persuasively for the values of our society. Generalising and including a great many people who should not be included in this war against terror will only add to the potency of the arguments of the terrorists, who must be marginalised, weeded out of our society and punished appropriately.

talk.start.para: âIt is 12 October, around 11.15 p.m. Balinese time. Young holiday-makers are relaxing and enjoying themselves. They have headed to Bali in search of a good time. Innocence prevails. Friendships are made. Inhibitions are vanquished to another time, another place. Kuta Beach is a place of good times and great people. Then, within a split second, a dream holiday becomes more than a nightmare. It is an apocalyptical scene of carnage and destruction, the like of which has never been seen before in our region. There are approximately 180 deaths, including 92 Australians, and many hundreds injured.

speech.para: Like all members of parliament, there are residents in my electorate of Paterson who have been greatly affected by the Bali bombings. Day after day we have seen the footage on TV and the pictures in the newspapers that have shown the tremendous heartache that families right across the country are feeling. It breaks your heart to hear the stories of survivors who have stayed on after the bombings to look for missing friends or family. And it breaks your heart to see families waiting in agony to hear even the smallest piece of information. They hang on in hope. Many people have lost friends, mothers, fathers, brothers and sisters, sons and daughters, and it is a loss that our whole nation is feeling. It is one of the worst tragedies that our nation has ever witnessed and it has taken the lives of so many of our fine young people. It is these people who were having the time of their lives in Bali. We have heard so many stories of families and friends staying in local resorts on post-season football celebrations or on surfing holidays.

My heart and the prayers of the people of Paterson go out to each and every one of these families who have been personally affected by this tragedy. Bali has a special place in the hearts of many Australians. So many people travel there because of the beautiful beaches and because it is a place to relax, and many make it an annual event. But it is the Balinese people that leave a lasting impression on most travellers through their warmth, sincerity and generosity. In particular, my heart goes out to my dear friends Garry and Deslie Shakespeare from Raymond Terrace in my electorate, for their daughter, Melody Kariarta, lives in Bali. Melody has lived in Bali for nine years and lives there with her husband and four children. She owns a restaurant outside Kuta known as `Full Moon', which is a very popular eating place for many of the travellers.

On that fateful day, Melody's daughter, Oshar, had her 18th birthday party. It was a time when families should have been celebrating the whole night through. Melody took a friend to the airport in Bali, which delayed her return to Kuta by about an hour. When she came back from the airport, she was trying to find a car park space when the explosions took place. It may just have been this hour's delay that saved Melody's life and the members of her family. Deslie Shakespeare has told me how Melody and her family helped people from the start by volunteering at the hospital. Her son-in-law, Wayan Kariarta, started pulling bodies out of the wreckageâtourists from Australia and other nations as well as the local Balinese people who were critically injured and killed.

What Deslie's family saw and lived through is something that I cannot describe in words. Fortunately, Deslie will be travelling to Bali soon to be with her family. I wish her and her family the very best during these very difficult times. As I speak, the Kariarta family are dining with the Governor-General and other people affected by the tragedy in Bali tonight. The doctors, the nurses, the volunteers and the Australian authorities who have assisted the injured, regardless of their nationality, have been doing a tremendous job in Bali.

I congratulate all of the emergency services, the RAAF and the volunteers who reacted so quickly and have performed an amazing job under these very difficult circumstances. The stories of volunteers who do not have any medical training but who were just sitting and comforting the injured is just inspirational. Over time, more brave stories will come out of this tragedy involving not only Australians but Balinese people and those of other nationalities. How this tragedy will affect Bali, its people and its economy is something that will only unfold over time. Not only is this a tragedy for the Australian families who have lost loved ones but I recognise it is also a tragedy for the Balinese people.

The Australian government and authorities are working with their Indonesian counterparts to ensure that they find and bring to justice as quickly as possible those responsible for this terrible act. The horrible loss of life reinforces the absolute necessity of taking robust action to eliminate the threat that confronts us all. Nations must work together to stamp out terrorism, which threatens the lives of innocent people. In the wake of the events in Bali the government has announced a review of both the adequacy of domestic terrorism legislation and our counter-terrorism capacity. While both were recently reviewed, the terrorist attack in Bali makes another review a matter of responsibility to all Australians. It would be irresponsible of the government not to do everything within its power to ensure the safety and security of its citizens. We must make sure that we are in the best position possible to identify and punish those responsible for the terrorist acts and to foil those planning terrorist acts.

The government is committed to doing everything it can to bring those responsible for this despicable act to justice. Cooperation between the Australian and Indonesian governments is essential in pursuit of those responsible for the unprovoked, indiscriminate slaughter of human life. We must and will direct all available resources, including the might of the law, to protecting our community and working to ensure that those responsible for threatening our security are brought to justice, and we will do so as swiftly as possible.

Finally, I say how proud I am of our Prime Minister, John Howard; Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson; and Leader of the Opposition, Simon Crean, who went to Bali to help comfort the victims and their families. What impressed me most is that they were prepared to stay there and listen to the stories and comfort people until they were no longer needed. That is the hallmark of a leader and a statesman. Our Prime Minister has done everything he can, everything within his power, to make it just a little bit easier for these people. Unfortunately, time is the only thing that will help heal these wounds. All I say in conclusion is may those who have been lost to us rest in peace with God.

talk.start.para: âIt is very hard for us, not having been part of that horror, to imagine the horror which was visited on all those who suffered as a result of the terrorist attacks in Bali last week. We saw the photographs of the young people cavorting in the pool just hours before some of them were killedâyoung lives which were snuffed out and destroyed well before their time in circumstances where they were completely innocent and completely oblivious as to what was to happen to them. We also know of so many people who are now suffering hideous injuries and have to try to rebuild their lives in circumstances where they have gone through extreme pain and suffered over an extended period of time.

speech.para: We are aware of the courage and the heroism of people who risked their own lives to save others and put the welfare of others before their own. The Bali bombing is an event which has brought out the worst in human nature but at the same time it has brought out the best in human nature, and those of us in the comfortable circumstances that we are in can only stand in awe and marvel at the courage of those who risked their own lives to save others. I do not know them. I do know of Jason McCartney, as so many Melbourne people do, as a Kangaroos footballer. That story of his heroism in putting the welfare of others before his own and prejudicing his own health in the process is an interesting thing. It shows that people have all sorts of sides to their characters and that tragic circumstances can bring out real heroism in people in the way that the Bali terrorism has done.

On behalf of the people of the electorate of Wills, I want to convey our solidarity, our sympathy and our condolences to the families and friends of those who were killed and injured in the Bali bombing. In this time of profound anguish and grief, where the world must seem surreal to those who live on, I want them to know that the hearts of the people of Wills are with them. I also wish to convey our appreciation of the efforts of the medical staff and the volunteers. They do colossal work in unimaginably difficult and trying circumstances. I also want to mention the people who are sifting the remains to identify bodies. This is gruesome and horrible work, and we are all very much in their debt.

After the terrorist attacks of 11 September in New York on the World Trade Centre, I issued on behalf of the people of Wills and indeed to the people of Wills a call for tolerance and respect for everybody, no matter what their religion or racial background. I pointed out that Australia is a country which is founded on toleranceâit is really our chief virtueâand we have been a successful model of tolerance and indeed a beacon to the rest of the world. There are so many places around the world where people from different religious backgrounds and different racial backgrounds have been unable to live successfully together. We have done that successfully in this country. I believed then, and still believe, that tolerance has served this country well and that we should stick with tolerance.

I have many Islamic people in my electorate. They are horrified and appalled by this crime. They identify as Australians and feel for the plight of those who suffered as a result of the bombing. Their world has become less safe as a result of this, in the same way as the world of the rest of us has become less safe as a result of this. I have quite a strong connection with the Turkish Muslim community in my electorate. They understand the separation between church and state very well. They have been left a fine legacy by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. They understand that religion is the sphere of the privateâit should be the sphere of the privateâand that matters of law and politics, which are the sphere of the public, are not an appropriate place for religion.

I repeat the call for tolerance that I made last time. Australia remains a terrific place in which to live and we must not let any of these sorts of things prejudice or undermine that. It would give the terrorists a real victory if that were to happen. I also encourage moderate Islamic organisations to denounce the extremists and to make clear, as we must all make clear, that there is no place for religious fanaticism or fundamentalism of whatever stripeâwhether it is Muslim, Hindu, Jewish, Protestant or Catholic. We must denounce and reject the kind of fundamentalism or fanaticism that says it is okay to kill and maim in the pursuit of some religious goal.

I also want to express in the strongest possible terms my opposition to the view that I occasionally hear around the place that in some respect Australians might have had it coming to them in terms of the political positions that we have adopted or our role in the war on terrorism. There was, and has been, an element of this post-September 11âthis kind of idea that the United States might have had it coming to them because of some of their international policies. There is a suggestion that Australia might have had this coming to us because of some of our international political positions. This is outrageous. Terrorists alone are responsible for these outrages, and the implication that this act might in some respect be justified is absolute nonsense. Indeed, it is my view that the only thing which some of these terroristsâ the likes of Osama bin Ladenâunderstand is strength and a willingness to combat that, and the idea that if we are polite to terrorists we might avoid problems for ourselves is nonsense. The only way we can proceed is to continue to prosecute the war on terrorism and make it clear that in no sense are we prepared to accept this kind of behaviour or back away from it.

I do make the point that I think that some of the things that have been said about Iraq may not be relevant to the war on terrorism. From my own point of view, the link has not been satisfactorily made out between the Iraqi leadership and al-Qaedaâthe work of Osama bin Ladenâand international terrorism generally. If people want take that war on terrorism into Iraq, they need to produce more and better evidence than has been produced to date.

In conclusion, we must all joinâindeed, we have all joinedâtogether at what is a very difficult moment in this nation's history to support and comfort and grieve alongside those who have suffered and who have lost loved ones. As I said at the outset, my heart goes out to them, and we wish them as speedy a recovery as can be possibly achieved in these circumstances.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to support the Prime Minister's motion condemning the recent acts of violence in Bali. Last Sunday I attended a service for the national day of mourning in my hometown of Albury, a town that has lost a lovely young woman, Andrea Hore, who is missing in that place. My heart goes out to Andrea's family, her workmates and her friends. This and other services conducted throughout the day were an opportunity for all of us to express our sorrow, to offer our deep sympathy to families of the victims and to feel part of a strong and determined nation of Australians who will not bow down to terrorism.

speech.para: I know I join with all of the people of Farrer, whom I represent here in parliament, in a common bond of fellowship as we condemn this cruel and callous taking of life. We also feel great pride in the acts of selflessness and bravery and the sheer hard work and commitment shown by survivors, medical personnel, other tourists, our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Federal Police. While the loss of Australian life was tragic enough, we also recognise the loss of citizens of other countries as well as the local Balinese people, none of whom deserved this wicked and monstrous act.

People have naturally reacted with horror and disbelief. Those of us who grew up in a world largely untouched by such events have suddenly realised that, more than ever before, the world is a villageâcloser than we thought and less safe than we thought. I think it is important to remember, at a time when we feel so threatened, that in many respects we have been here before. Australia has been through two world wars; in fact, World War II came to our shores 60 years ago this year and we prevailed against an unthinkable horror. Our parents' generation and their parents' generation knew that unthinkable horror, lived with it daily and found the strength to carry on. As we search for inspiration to guide us through this difficult time, there is no better place to find it than in the examples of Australian men and women who defended this country from aggression and built it back up after the fighting was over.
During the national day of mourning service we heard words of inspiration and prayer from Mother Theresa, part of which read:

quote.para: What you spend years building, someone could destroy overnight; Build anyway.

speech.para: There is no doubt that on the night of Saturday, 12 October, a great deal was destroyed that had taken many lifetimes to build. Young people's lives were being built as they took their place in the world; relationships were being built between partners, between parents, between families; the close and friendly relationship between Australia and Indonesia, especially Bali, which has existed over such a long period was being built upon all the time. With these barbaric bombings, all of this was destroyed overnight.
As we try to make sense of the senseless and try to come to terms with a world that seems broken and divided as never before, these words of Mother Theresa which I have mentioned are important:

quote.para: What you spend years building, someone could destroy overnight; Build anyway.

speech.para: After our period of loss and mourning we will, in true Australian spirit, gather our confidence, our free spirit and our bright and happy souls and build again. Those of us who struggle with the grief that we feel should remember that Alexander Pushkin said:

quote.para: As long as there is one heart on earth where I still live, my memory will not die ...

speech.para: The people lost and killed in Bali will go on living in the hearts of all Australians. Love is stronger than death and, for those who love, time is an eternity.

What can be said about terrorism and violence? Those who use it reject the basic machinery of civilisation. Those who practise terrorismâin this case, mass murderâseek to make civilisation unworkable. It has been said that there is only one step from fanaticism to barbarism. The extremists who have committed these crimes have taken that step and they must be stopped from taking it again. In Enemies of Society, Paul Johnson said:

quote.para: The virtue we should cherish most is the courage to resist violence, especially if this involves flying in the face of public opinion which, in its fear and in its anxiety for peace, is willing to appease the violators. Above all, violence should never be allowed to pay, or be seen to pay ...

speech.para: As we strengthen our determination to fight evil and terror, it is important that we in no way see this as a crime perpetrated by Islam. In common with Christianity and other faiths, Muslims regard human life as a gift from God. There are a large number of Muslims in Indonesia, indeed all over the world, but very few are extremists. The Prophet, whom the Muslim world follows, never resorted to or approved of the murder of innocent people. It is necessary that we take up the challenge to stare down all perpetrators of violence, accepting that the only perspective they have is terror. Although they may claim to be acting in the name of a religious faith, they are not. In fact, Muslims are ordered to be respectful of other faiths. Islam is a religion that teaches its followers that they must let other religions be, as long as those other religions are living peacefully in their midst. Terrorists who consider themselves martyrs to a wonderful Islamic cause are deceiving themselves and they offend their own faith just as much as they offend other faiths.

Soon we will be concentrating on the detail of the defence and foreign policy issues that this event presents us withâon our review of counterterrorist measures and on security at home and abroad. After our first concern for the victims and their families, this government is prepared and getting on with all these things. But now is a time to reflect, to grieve, to feel our common sorrow and our common humanity, as we prepare for the special interdenominational memorial service which is to be held in Canberra this Thursday for the families whose hearts are breaking. We must cherish and remember the ones who have been lost, as we do whatever we can to offer whatever comfort we can. In remembering our fine young Australians, I read this poem by Rupert Brooke for them:

quote.para: These hearts were woven of human joys and cares,
Washed marvellously with sorrow, swift to mirth.
The years had given them kindness. Dawn was theirs,
And sunset, and the colours of the earth.
These had seen movement, and heard music; known
Slumber and waking; loved; gone proudly friended;
Felt the quick stir of wonder; sat alone;
Touched flowers and furs and cheeks. All this is ended.
There are waters blown by changing winds to laughter
And lit by the rich skies, all day. And after,
Frost, with a gesture, stays the waves that dance
And wandering loveliness. He leaves a white
Unbroken glory, a gathered radiance,
A width, a shining peace, under the night.

talk.start.para: âWe were all shocked and dazed by the terrible explosions that occurred in Bali on the night of Saturday, 12 October. The stories that came out of the grief and heroism and just sheer guts and determination make one very proud but terribly sad about the human cost of this tragedy to our country and to the people of Indonesia, including those of Bali. We are not used to events of this kind occurring so close to us. We are not prepared for knowing what it is like to survive so terrible an event as this. It brings home only too clearly what American families went through on 11 September last year.

speech.para: I give my heartfelt condolences to all those who have lost loved ones and still have family members missing. It is a hard time, a terrible time. All those in my electorate of Lyons are thinking of those people. I was able to speak a few words last Sunday at Oaklands, a town in the heart of my electorate of Lyons in Tasmania. Many people of that town and those visiting for the day wore sprigs of wattle for our day of mourning. Many people of that region observed that minute of silence. I am sure that all members of my electorate offer their sympathies to the many families throughout Australia that suffered loss.

In the days and months that follow, we will hear many stories about acts of heroism. It was incredible to hear that many people were saved because they had a mate or a friend still there in better circumstances than they were. They pulled people out. They were able to get them to help. They continued to assist their friends. This was one thing that kept coming out of the reports on this great tragedy.

We must not forget the people who have survived this terrible ordeal. We, as a community, must help them return to their normal lives where that is possible. The hardest part of any tragedy is that those who survive have to pick up the pieces of their lives. After a few months the public can forget, but the impact of this ordeal on many of the injured will endure for their lifetime and we must be big enough to remember them in 10 years time. I hope some of the ideas that are presently being passed aroundâparticularly the idea of a hospital as a memorialâcan gain some credence and become reality. I hope that, as soon as we can, we will start planning so that we can help those who survived to get back into good health. This will be Australia's real challenge. It will be a challenge to assist those people in a proper manner.

I remember seeing a new skin graft process by a Perth hospital. The person's own cells are sprayed on. It is a revolutionary process that certainly breaks down and stops a lot of scarring in burn victims. It is a very major thing. Those people have worked extremely hard and people have benefited from their research and surgical skills. I pay tribute to them. I hope that process will be more available to the world in the future.

Our thanks must go to those who helped in the care and search for survivors, those who identified those lost in this tragedy, those who worked in the hospitals in Bali and those who did what they could to help families search for their own. These people showed what it means to be Australian and be part of our nation's family. We are as one always in these times.

I must also mention the sadness I feel for the Balinese. They have suffered as much as we have; their people have died too. Along with the people they lost, many of their jobs and means of existence will also disappear. Bali is a magnificently beautiful place with a different approach to life from many other areas in Indonesia. The shock to their culture and existence must be equal to, if not more than, the shock to ours in this country. To the people of Bali, I offer my condolences and concern, and hope that in some way Australia and Bali can be more strongly linked after this tragedy.

We need to remember our police presence and our intelligence officers that are in the field up there at the present time trying to find the perpetrators of the attack. The work that they are doing hopefully will come to some fruition in the future. I am sure that all Australians will be giving them their best endeavours as well.

We all remember other tragedies in Australia. When the Bali bombings happened, I remembered Port Arthur in my own electorate. I am sure that the member opposite, Mr Nairn, remembers when the tragedy occurred at Thredbo in his electorate. I remember him rising to speak in the House and trying to bring those things together, as I did for my own electorate. They are very heart-wrenching events and we all who are close to them then realise the human misery that it causes: the loss of hope and dreams for many families.

We need to concentrate on the future; we need to endeavour to resolve this and to find those who perpetrated it. We are never going to be able, in our present world, to take things lightly for many years. We will need to be on guard. There are people who are determined to impose their causes and beliefs on the rest of the world, and we will certainly need to be very strong and protect our way of life against that. As a parent, I feel like all other parents who have children who travel and spend time in other parts of the world. It is a very frightening time in the sense that you take on within yourself a certain amount of fear and you need to overcome that at times like these.

I wish to pass on special thanks to all the Qantas airline people who were involved in bringing people home from Bali. I also want to thank our defence forces, which in recent times have been called upon by our country to do extraordinary work, and they always perform to a very high level. They set their benchmarks high and when we call upon them they seem to more than meet those benchmarks. I have great respect for them and I thank them for all the work that they have done.

The other day during the welcome of the new German ambassador with the German-Australian Parliamentary Friendship, the German ambassador mentioned that Australia, without having been asked, had helped bring back to Australia 10 German nationals who needed assistance. He was very grateful and praised us as a country for always being willing to assist friends and people from other nations. It was a great tribute to receive, and I mention it now so that others can share it.
We have all suffered, and I can only once again pass on my deepest condolences and sympathies to all those who have lost friends and families in this tragedy.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âAt this stage I am not aware of any victims from my electorate of Lindsay. However, I have no doubt that some of my constituents have experienced the loss of someone close, someone they knew, someone they had been to school with, someone young. I think having to bury a child is every parent's nightmare. In the normal course of things, parents expect to pass away before their children. I think the hardest thing anyone would have to do would be to deal with the loss of someone so young in whom you have invested so much and for whom you had such great hopes. That was my immediate reaction on hearing the news of these incomprehensible attacks on young Australians in a holiday spot like Bali.

speech.para: I felt like tucking my family close around me on Fortress Australia, keeping them close to me and not letting them off this continentâ`I won't let them grow up; I'll keep them safe from the bad man'. Yet I know in my heart of hearts my children will grow up to be just like meâthey will leave school, leave university and want to see the world. They will save their pennies and get some very cheap fare off this great continent and they will go a long way and for a long time. There are very many young Australians travelling and seeing the world for six months or up to two years. It is just such a long way, and we know that when we come back from travelling the world and we create our lives in what is the best country in the worldâwe have seen the world and we know this to be trueâit will be a long time before we get off these shores again. My husband is going to China next week, and I am nervous about that. Again, I want to hold him close and say, `Don't go. Stay close to me; stay safe.'

There are conflicting emotions. Do we build Fortress Australia? Do we isolate ourselves and think that we can somehow protect our children, or do we go forth into the world and try to make the world a safer place? Do we extend our compassion and our understanding to those in Bali who have also lost their loved ones? In a time of national tragedy when we are mourning our own Australians, are we capable of understanding their devastating loss? What about those workers in the Sari bar who were the sole breadwinners of a Balinese family? How is that family going to cope in a nation that does not provide social security? It does not even provide the hospital care and health care that we take for granted in a developed nation. This happened in a developing nation.

I do know the situation quite accurately from the three years I lived in Malaysia with the RAAF. I rode a motorbike. I was young; I was silly; I was six foot tall and bulletproofâand nothing was going to happen. But I always remember telling my mates, `If anything does happenâif I have a motorbike accidentâwill you please just fill me with pethidine and get me on a Hercules back to Darwin and let them deal with me there. Do not send me to a hospital in a developing world.' I suppose the main fear was infection. You could have the most basic of injuries but things just went horribly wrong. I remember a story in the media of a plastic surgeon who happened to be in Bali and went to offer services in the hospital, and there was just nothing there for him to do anything with. He could not even apply any of his skills or any of his training because there was not even any basic equipment in the hospital. I know the Prime Minister is thinking of a permanent Australian memorial in Bali in terms of a fully equipped hospital and maybe some sort of training scheme with an exchange system, where some of the Indonesian personnel can be trained up in terms of medical standards and they can be given some comfort so that, if people are injured, there is medicine available and a bit more than the very basic care that was available.

To that end, I do have to commend the wonderful effort of the RAAF personnel who got the injured back home to Australia within 48 hours of the event. I remember I trained in the RAAF for those types of events, and we moved our equipment and personnel around. I have done the trip from Richmond to Darwin and from Darwin to Penang on the rattly old Herc. It is an incredibly boring trip, sitting in the back of a darkened cargo compartment with only tiny basic lights. You cannot see; there are no windows to look out. I can just imagine what the scene would have been like on those flights coming home.

I send my sincere congratulations on a job well done to the RAAF medical and other personnel who were involved in that evacuation. I have trained with our medical teams and been on exercises with them, and they certainly know the drill. It is very comforting to know that, with little notice, they are able to gear up and deliver for Australia when the chips are down. I commend them for that. A number of people in my electorate would have been involved in that evacuation.

I commend the attitude of the Australians who were injured, when they went back into the Sari bar to look for their mates. That mateship is something we have known in the past; it is something that is strong enough to withstand attacks such as this. This week we saw the anniversary of the Battle of El Alamein. More than 2,694 Australians were killed and wounded in one of the most decisive, strategic and psychological battles of the war. In that war there were young men in the prime of their lives. I have a quote from Jean Parry, a nurse of the 2nd AIF. She said of the wounded:

quote.para: Oh, the boys were wonderful. The thing that I remember most about the boys is that they weren't thinking of themselves. They'd come into the hospital badly injuredâtheir main concern was their mates and wanting to know what happened to them.

speech.para: She could have been talking about the injured in the crowded clinics of Bali on the night of that tragic terrorist attack.

I think caution is now needed in the world that we live in. I would like to think that my children will be able to travel the world freely. I would like to think that they will have the experiences of backpacking through South America, South-East Asia and Europe that I did. I would like to think that they would then be able to make it home to Australia safely. At this stage, I do not have that comfort.

I am terribly concerned for young Australians travelling overseas and I really hope that we come through this as a nation. I hope that we come through it with the respect, tolerance, understanding and compassion that mark us as a Western nation. The fact that we are Western seems to have made us a target. We are free and democratic, and we tolerate views that are different views from oursâand there is no aggression around that. Yet, somehow, we are targeted for being Westernâthat is all you can put it down to. I do not think I would like my kids to grow up in anything other than a democratic and free society.

It is a troubling time. My heart goes out to all those who have lost someone or are waiting for results and to people who have been injured. I do not think there is a more horrific injury than extensive burns. I hope and pray for their recovery and I know that all of our medical personnel, right across the hospitals of Australia involved with the victims from this tragedy, will be working with them. As the Prime Minister said, they have 19 million mates all wishing them the very best.

talk.start.para: âI rise in the House to offer my condolences to the relatives and friends who have lost loved ones in the terrorist attack in Bali. It is a tragedy of immense proportions and our hearts go out to our fellow Australians who have had to cope with the grief and uncertainty that has no doubt disrupted and dominated their lives since October 12.

speech.para: It is hard to comprehend or understand how such an act of senseless barbarity and evil could be contemplated and carried out in such a ruthless and uncaring manner. Innocent Australians of varying ages on holidays in a popular destination frequented by many Australians have become the victims of what can only be described as a senseless, despicable and cowardly act of evil.

Last Sunday, I attended an ecumenical service at St Mary's Cathedral in Geelong, where the community came together as part of the national day of mourning to offer its support to Geelong families directly affected by this tragedy. The cathedral was packed with people determined to express their support to the Lee and Cartwright families in their hour of sorrow. The Lee family, it would appear, have lost three members of their family in this tragedy. May I convey to those families on behalf of the electors of Corio our strongest expression of support for them at this time of great sorrow and uncertainty in their lives.

The service was a beautiful one and our thanks go to Father Kevin Dylan and his co-celebrants from other faiths for the compassionate and sensitive remembrance and tribute to the Australians who are not coming home to their loved ones.

One cannot help but be moved by the extraordinary courage and selflessness demonstrated by many people in the wake of the terrible explosions that have shattered and ended many Australian lives. I pay tribute in this House to members of the Geelong Football Club, particularly to senior team member Tim `Bluey' McGrath, for their care and compassion for others following the blast. We know of the terrible tragedy that befell other sporting clubs on that day and, as we in Geelong have a very young football side, we literally shudder and go cold at the thought of the fate that might have befallen many of them as they holidayed at Kuta Beach in Bali. Thankfully, they escaped serious injury, and we honour the part they played in preparing bandages and assisting the wounded. We are grateful for Tim McGrath's presence of mind in an organisational sense and the great wisdom he displayed following the attack.

I have been heartened by the extraordinary contributions made by many people as we responded as a nation to this tragedy. It is that contribution that lifts our spirits and steels our resolve to bring the perpetrators to justice. I mention here the surgeons and nurses, the hospital workers, the police and emergency service personnel, the aid agencies, the public servants who provided such strong support and information to the government of the day and information to the families affected by this tragedy, and the transport and travel personnel. All have played their part in delivering compassionate support in the aftermath of the attack. The fibre of the nation has been tested in the most difficult circumstance, and ordinary Australians have done quite extraordinary things to help their fellow countrymen and to support those in greatest need.

At this time of national mourning, we ought to remember also the families of the people of many other nationalities who perished on that day, particularly the Balinese. I have been to Bali on several occasionsâonce with my son Adam, and the other as part of a parliamentary delegation in 1994. I was not only struck by the beauty of the island but also by the beautiful culture and the friendliness of the people. They possess a great love of life, and the suffering that has been visited upon them as a result of this senseless act of terrorism is quite beyond comprehension.

Many have said that Australia lost its innocence on 12 October. As a nation, we lost it long before that date. The callous attack on 12 October reminds us in a poignant way that we now live in even greater uncertain times. Living with uncertainty is nothing new to many of us. We were raised under the threat of nuclear war and the annihilation of our civilisation. We have learned to live with that threat. We have borne that burden during the tender years of our upbringing, just as our children must now bear the uncertainty we have introduced into their lives. We cannot now escape the responsibility placed upon us all to free the world from the shadow of terror that has now crept over their lives.

We have all felt enormous anger at the scenes of death and great suffering that have filled our screens as the events unfolded and were reported by the media. If we are going to construct a world free of violence, death and uncertainty, at some time we are going to have to put some of those feelings aside and commit ourselves in a very real way to the cause of peace for our children's sake. As a free and democratic nation, we have a special responsibility in the affairs of the world and the relationships that are conducted between nations.

Australia occupies a special place as a nation that enjoys a very high standard of living and a civility in its culture which at times is tested but in the main provides us with security and the ability to go about our daily lives free of the terror and the circumstances that befall many people in other parts of the world. Because of that special responsibility, we must ensure that we are an agent for peace in the international arena. Those who make the wars never really have to fight them. That has been an adage that I have lived with and that my father lived with. The previous speaker spoke of the battle of El Alamein. Our family was intimately involved in that particular struggle, but now we face a struggle of a different kind. It challenges us all to open our minds to the creative ways that we must now employ to ensure that we construct a peaceful world.

I went to Monash University. Many of us would have come through our university years and viewed the rather interesting graffiti that often adorned the walls of universities. I can recall one particular peace of graffiti which always stuck in my mind: `War is good business. Invest your sons now.' It had quite a profound impact upon me and I dedicated myself at that time to ensuring that Australians never had to fight in another war. Sadly, that has not been the case. We do not stop trying to construct a world where our children can go about their daily lives in peace and without uncertainty. That places great responsibilities on us here in this parliament to ensure that the actions that we take, in government and in opposition, are focused on the pursuit of peace and not the pursuit of war.

In conclusion, let me extend once again my deepest sympathies to all the families, particularly those in Geelong, who have been affected by this terrible tragedy. We will bring the perpetrators to justice one way or another. When justice is done, the enormous task of rebuilding our lives will continue and the enormous task of ridding the world of the uncertainty that has been created by events of this type will really have to proceed in earnest.

The nation will grow through this experience. It will grow stronger through this experience. This experience will not shatter the free and democratic society that we have come to enjoy and love. We will do everything in our power in this parliament and in the Australian community to secure a life free from uncertainty and free from death and destruction for our children.

talk.start.para: âIn supporting the Prime Minister's resolution at this late stage in the debate, I want to place on record, as so many members have done so eloquently and compassionately before me, my outrage and horror at the terrorist bombings in Bali that have killed and injured so many of our fellow countrymen and women. I also wish to offer my deepest condolences to the families of the deceased and best wishes to those recovering in hospital and at home. The events of 11 days ago were horrific in our nation's history. We do not yet know all the facts or all the details, but we know enough to appreciate just what a calculated and murderous act the bombings were. We know that the acts were not the random acts of a misguided individual; rather, they were premeditated acts by a group of terrorists who picked their target and planned to maximise death and destruction. We know enough to know that there were two bombs, designed to maximise the injury toll. We know that the perpetrators deliberately chose a venue in the location of the Sari Club, where they knew many Australians and other Westerners were concentrated. It was an attack designed to wreak horror on those on holiday in a place of happiness.

speech.para: As many speakers in this debate, from the Prime Minister down, have laid out so articulately, these attacks mark something of a turning point for Australia. They will result in a change of attitudes in Australian society and about Australia and the sort of country we are. First and foremost, they have fundamentally altered the historic assumption that Australia's isolation in a global sense guarantees safety from the horrors of other parts of the world, whether Europe, the Middle East or America. In the wake of September 11, so many said that the ease of the attacks on New York and Washington illustrated how the world had changed and become a more dangerous place. While many people said that these sorts of attacks could happen here and that they could happen anywhere, I do not think that many Australians in their heart of hearts thought that that was realistically a possibility. While they said that this could happen, I did not think that they really thought that it would happen here.

While this tragedy has not happened in Australia, it is as close as it can beâin Bali, in our backyard. What happened will alter the attitude of Australians. We will not go back to where we were before last Saturday, 12 October 2002. It is important that we understand as a nation just what is at stake in the war against terror. As many commentators and speakers in this debate have said, we lost something last Saturday in terms of innocence. The bombings illustrate in a very devastating way that no-one is immune from the war on terror.

The terrorists who are perpetrating this war are not fighting nations. The attitude of the extremists who are fighting is motivated not by a desire to destroy a particular nation but rather by a desire to destroy a lifestyle, a culture, a set of values and a way of lifeâthat is, Western democracy. It is not the flag of a nation or a group of nations that they oppose and want to destroy. It is the way of life of those nations and the way we live our lives. It is the freedom which we take for granted that they seek to destroy in a mad quest of extremism. In saying that, we must recognise that no Western nation can ignore those who seek to destroy our way of life, and every Western nation must fully be part of the war on terror because ignoring the terrorists will not make them go away. Not confronting the terrorists will not make them go away; it will actually make them grow stronger and wreak more damage and destruction in the futureâpossibly even more than we saw last Saturday in Bali and a year ago in the United States.

In the remaining time available, I will briefly touch on a couple of aspects of the strength of the Australian community and the response throughout the Australian community to this tragedy. We have heard so much about the wonderful response from the Department of Defence, the emergency services and the many people on the ground in Bali, and I echo that their magnificent contribution has once again shown how, in times of trial, Australians can really pull together. I also want to pay tribute to the wonderful spirit of the Australian community in the suburbs and the cities across our country. Our people have rallied together magnificently in a difficult time.

I was fortunate enough to attend a church service on Sunday, as many members would also have done. I attended the Mount Evelyn Christian Fellowship. It is a church that has a great deal to do with Indonesia. They have worked so hard for such a long period of time to provide aid and support for people in need in some of the outer provinces. They know only too well the difficulties that have been present in Indonesia with regard to Islamic extremism. On Sunday, hundreds of people turned up wearing their wattle to mourn the loss of life of those killed in Bali and to pray for those who are still fighting for their lives in hospitals across Australia. I mention this not because it is an unusual story but rather because it is very much the story of Australia last Sunday: a story of Australians joining together as one, to mourn together, to rally together for the best of what our nation stands for.

Like so many others around the nation, the people of Mount Evelyn Christian Fellowship have compassionate hearts and a commitment to helping others. Pastor Alan Meyer and all those involved in the church want to see an end to terrorism, and they want to see people live in peace and safety. Their tangible commitment has resulted in land being purchased to provide homes and a livelihood for those who have already suffered previous acts of terror and religious extremism. Medical training is also being provided, again to help those suffering needlessly. It will be the hard work and commitment of groups like this, as well as the commitment and hard work of leaders, nations and world bodies, that will be sorely needed in the future to secure better prospects for people in Indonesia and right throughout our region.
Debate (on motion by Mr Nairn) adjourned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 402, has Bankstown Airport now been sold; if so when and to whom; if not, who is the current owner of Bankstown Airport.
(2) If Bankstown Airport has been sold, what is now the date prescribed in the Airports Act 1996 Guidelines upon which the owner of Bankstown Airport is required to draft and table its Master Plan.
(3) To whom is the Master Plan to be furnished a copy.
(4) Is the Master Plan a public document; if not, why not.

(5) Further to the answers to parts (4) and (5) of question No. 402, were the number of aircraft movements a material factor in the sale of (a) Bankstown Airport and (b) Sydney Airport; if so, what commercial, environmental and safety issues does he understand to be relevant factors when considering the sale of Sydney Airport and Bankstown Airport.

(6) In light of his answers to parts (4) and (5) of question No. 402, can he explain upon what basis Sydney Airport was sold when, citing his answer to part (3) of question No. 402, the projected figures are not available.
(7) Was Sydney Airport sold without the availability of the data described in part (3) of question No. 402.
(8) Is he able to say what financial, environmental and safety impacts the forecast aircraft traffic increase on Bankstown Airport will have flowing from the decision to sell Sydney Airport.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. Bankstown Airport is currently leased on a long-term basis from the Commonwealth to Bankstown Airport Limited, a fully Commonwealth owned company.
(2) I refer the honourable member to answer (1) above, and to my reply to part (3) of Question 402.

(3) and (4) Under the Airports Act 1996 the airport lessee is required to make the draft master plan available for public comment for 90 days prior to submission to the Minister. (5) (a) See answer (1) above. (b) Airport movement statistics for Bankstown Airport were available to prospective buyers for Sydney Airport.

(6) It was a matter for the prospective buyers for Sydney Airport to take appropriate account of the Government's position regarding the possible future development of Bankstown Airport as an overflow airport.
(7) Yes.
(8) These matters will be addressed in the development of any specific proposal to upgrade facilities and operational aspects of Bankstown Airport.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Do the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Telecommunications Code of Practice 1997 currently allow mobile telephone low impact facilities to be installed without the need for (a) a Local Council Development Application and (b) written notification from the communications carrier to local residents and businesses potentially affected by such installations, with the exception of the owner and occupier of the property where such facilities are installed.

(2) Under the code, is the level of electromagnetic radiation emissions not a valid ground for an objection to the location of a mobile telephone low impact facility even when a person may believe that the proposed location would result in harmful exposure to such radiation; if so, why.
(3) Is a new code being developed for mobile telephone low impact facilities; if so, when will it come into force; if not, why not.

(4) Will any new code require telecommunications carriers to consult more fully with local councils and the community, even when a development application is not required for a low impact facility; if so, how; if not, why not.

(5) Will any new code require telecommunications carriers to notify all potentially-affected residents and businesses of a proposed installation of a mobile telephone low impact facility and allow them an opportunity to object to such an installation on health or environmental grounds; if so, how; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Carriers seeking to install low-impact facilities are required to comply with the rules of conduct set out in Schedule 3 to the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Telecommunications Code of Practice 1997. The Code requires that carriers notify landholders and occupiers regarding the installation of low-impact facilities. However, it is not a requirement of the Act or the Code for carriers to request a Local Council Development Application or consult with neighbouring businesses and residents.

(2) Yes. Carriers are currently required to comply with the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) mandatory limits for general public exposure to Radio Frequency EMR. The Government has rigorous standards making processes for all EMR emitting communications equipment, including mobile towers. The Australian Radiation and Nuclear Safety Agency develops these standards based on the best objective scientific information and advice available and in 2000 found that emissions from mobile phone base stations are on average thousands of times below the maximum permitted in strict international safety standards.

(3) A new Telecommunications Code of Practice is not being developed. However, the Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF) has developed an Industry Code for the Deployment of Radiocommunications Infrastructure, including mobile phone network facilities which augments the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Telecommunications Code of Practice 1997. The Code was registered by the ACA on 10 October 2002 and it is expected to be fully operational by 10 April 2003. The Industry Code is binding on all carriers.

(4) The Industry Code provides for a significant expansion of consultative practices required by carriers with affected community members including local councils, neighbouring residents, businesses and those in community sensitive locations. In the first instance, carriers will be required to notify affected communities of the consultation process, and resolve any issues of concern by direct negotiation.

(5) The Industry Code extends the obligations on carriers, particularly in relation to the consideration of radiation exposure and community consultation, and requires carriers to notify potentially affected residents and businesses providing adequate time for consultation. Objections in relation to performance of any mandatory obligation, including compliance with the `precautionary approach' for the building and operation of radio-based telecommunications equipment requiring best practice processes for demonstrating compliance with relevant exposure limits, may be lodged through a complaint mechanism allowed for in the Code.

Under the Telecommunications Code of Practice 1997, carriers have additional notice requirements to the Environment Secretary who may determine that carriers may not engage in low-impact facility activities due to environmental issues.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the report under section 24 of the Air Passenger Ticket Levy (Collection) Act 2001, is $350 million estimated to be the cost of employee entitlements under the Special Employee Entitlements Scheme for Ansett group employees (SEESA); if not, what is the estimated full amount.

(8) What (a) are the costs to date and (b) is the total estimated final cost of the costs incurred by the Departments referred to in part (7).

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Beyond those entitlements covered by the Government's SEESA scheme, the issue of any further entitlements of Ansett workers is a matter for the Administrators of the Ansett Group of companies.
(3) Yes.
(4) See Air Passenger Ticket Levy (Collection) Act 2001 s 23. The Government has indicated that any surplus monies will be returned with an emphasis on helping the tourism industry.

- 12,169 Ansett mainline employees
- 34 Showgroup employees
- 549 Kendall employees
- 14 Aeropelican employees; and

(6) I would refer the Honourable Member to the Ansett Administrators Third Report to Creditors which canvasses this matter in detail.

The final costs will be subject to the duration of the Ansett Administration including the timing of (a) further redundancies and (b) dividend payments - it is not possible to provide an estimate at this time.

subdebateinfo.title: Aviation: Essendon Airport Air Traffic Control
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 698)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is it correct that the Air Traffic Control (ATC) at Essendon Airport is closed between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., and that Melbourne ATC is responsible for Essendon air traffic control during this time.
(2) When, and why, was the decision taken to close Essendon Airport ATC between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m.

(3) Do pilots landing at, or taking off from, Essendon Airport between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. have to seek clearance from Melbourne Airport ATC; if so, what sort of communication takes place between pilots and ATC during landings and takeoffs at that time.
(4) Are there any differences between the procedures to be followed by pilots using Essendon Airport when the Essendon ATC is, and is not, operating.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Essendon Tower hours are:
Monday to Friday 6.15am - 10.00pm
Saturday 7.00am - 10.00pm
Sunday 8.00am - 10.00pm
Outside tower hours, the Air Traffic Services for Essendon aerodrome are provided through the Melbourne Centre.
(2) The overnight closure of Essendon was introduced in June 1993. The reason for the overnight closure was the low level of aircraft movements at night.
(3) Yes. Outside tower hours, pilots establish communication with the Melbourne Centre whilst on the ground at Essendon to receive airways clearances and ATC instructions.

Mr Anderson

quote.para: (5) The Sturt highway has duplicated carriageways at the Gawler Bypass of 7.5km, and the section through Renmark Township.

Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The honourable member's questions refer mainly to New South Wales and are predominantly State issues. However, I have ascertained the following information:

(1) There is no commonly accepted definition of what constitutes a âteaching hospitalâ. Nonetheless, it is generally accepted that teaching hospitals have a major academic focus and provide a wide range of specialist services. Given the lack of clear definition, it is not possible to precisely state the exact number of such hospitals. The best estimate currently available to the Department of Health and Ageing is that there are nine such hospitals in NSW that have Medicare eligible MRI services, listed below:
Â· John Hunter Hospital (Newcastle)
Â· Liverpool Hospital (Liverpool)
Â· Nepean Hospital (Penrith)
Â· Prince of Wales/Prince Henry Hospital (includes the children's campus, Randwick)
Â· Royal North Shore Public Hospital (St Leonards)
Â· Royal Prince Alfred Hospital (Camperdown)
Â· Westmead Hospital (Westmead)
Â· The New Children's Hospital (Westmead)
Â· St George Hospital (Kogarah)
(2) Nine of the 26 Medicare eligible MRI sites in NSW, almost one third, are at the above hospitals.

(3) In addition to the teaching hospitals listed in the answer to Question (1) that operate Medicare eligible MRI units, I understand there are four other such hospitals in NSW. The additional four are:
Â· St Vincent's Public Hospital (Darlinghurst)
Â· Wollongong Hospital (Wollongong)
Â· Concord Hospital (Concord)
Â· Gosford Hospital Gosford)
(4) The relevant suburbs, for eligible MRI units, are included in the answer to Question (1) above. Such hospitals tend to be clustered close to the major population centres and business districts.
(5) It is estimated that nine of the 13 teaching hospitals or close to 70% provide Medicare eligible MRI services
(6) The Commonwealth does not have information on this matter. I would suggest that the honourable member may wish to direct this question to the NSW Minister for Health for advice.

(7) As indicated in my answer to the same question raised by the honourable member and answered in this House on 19 August 2002, advice received from the MRI Monitoring and Evaluation Group indicates that there are sufficient MRI services available in metropolitan Sydney. It is not possible to indicate when Concord Hospital would be entitled to a MRI licence.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Tertiary students includes students who are enrolled at universities and students who are enrolled in vocational education and training at institutions such as TAFE.
Numbers of students enrolled in tertiary studies in specified postcodes

(2) (3), (4) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has provided the information below by postcode on the numbers of students enrolled in semester one 2002 who have a HECS debt, and those who are not currently enrolled but have a HECS debt.

The ATO data on HECS debtors uses the address for the mailing of annual HECS statements, that is, the student's permanent home address. However, the data for current university enrolments by postcode refers to the postcode where the student resides during the term/semester. Therefore, there may be currently enrolled students who have a HECS debt whose permanent home address is in the specified postcode area but whose term/semester address is in another postcode area. This results in some occurrences of data for current university enrolments being a lesser figure than the figure for students currently enrolled who have a HECS debt (eg. postcode 2046 below).
